text: Pours dark amber with a beige head. SMell is funky and light caramel. Taste is watery, light caramel. Not much going on here flavorwise. Medium body and high carbonation. Decent, but boring.

Nez: Malté, pomme, fruits mûrs
Bouche: Maltée, caramel, pomme, poire, épicée
Une très bonne bière de garde goutée à Absolument Bieres Votre Biershop

Man, man, man hoelang was dit geleden. Donker amberkleurig bier met een rode gloed en crèmekleurige schuimkraag. Geur: licht zoet, karamel, wat fruitig en kruidig. Smaak: gistkarakter, granen, licht zoet en een bittertje. Goede koolzuurprikkel.
Bottle at home, amber beer, small head, aroma is malt, caramel. Taste is the same, bit sweet. nice one.

Bottle, 0.25l. Cloudy amber brown color with thin creamy tan-like head, yeast residue and soft visible carbonation. Aroma of caramel, dandelion syrup, malt, cloves and grassy hops. Taste starts with light to moderate sweet caramel malt, follows by fruity, yeasty and bready acidity with mild spicy mouthfeel and moderate bitter finish. Medium body, slick texture and fizzy carbonation in palate. Collossal letdown, expected to give rating higher than 4.2...

Ahhhh.Je redeviens fière dêtre français bierologiquement parlant.
Robe dun ambre sublime.Petit col mousseux blanc cassé.Nez de biscuit, de caramel, de cassonade, petite amertume sensible, petite acidité.On y retrouve la même palette sur la langue, les arômes les uns se autres se mélangeant sans se confondre.Merci mon caviste, belle recommandation.

Pours a reddish orange with a good head and nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is honey and soft nuttiness, richly malty... but not overly sweet smelling, with mild notes of noble hops and leaf rot. 

The flavor is earthy but sweet up front, nutty, with a good balance from leafy and earthy hops and the soft bitterness they exude... some mild honey, with a semi dry finish. 

Its got a remarkable balance going on in both the aroma and the flavor, not many beers pull off a malt character like this one does, my hat is off.

Déçu! ! Pour lune des meilleures bières française je mattendais a bien plus surprenant. Au lieu de ça je me retrouve avec une ambrées bonne mais presque fade. Cest malté et caramel, cest plutôt cool mais ça manque grave de patate. Je la conseille au petit déjeuner pour en profiter pleinement .

Clear amber colour, cream head. Malty aroma, caramel, green banana, yeast. Malty flavour, caramel, light mineral notes, hint of bitterness. Malty finish, lingering bitter, mineral notes.
(from 75cL bottle @ Benzai. Thanks for sharing, Rene!)

Bottle @ benzai thx to benzai. Amber colour with a small to medium sized beige head. Smells slightly glue-ish.. Not a whole lot of smell. Tastes malty, some caramel, sweetish.. A bit boring. Soft carbo, thin to medium best. Shouldnt be the best beer from France. Mont Saleve destroyes stuff like this.

Bottle [from trade with EricKok] @ weekly tasting. Clear amber to red color, medium sized off-white head. Smell malts, caramel, oatmeal somehow, sweetish. Taste malts, slightly some sweetness, sweet caramel, brown sugar. Medium body and carbonation.

750mL bottle, pours an opaque dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma brings out lots oak, wet wood, very dry cardboard-like notes, and some farmhouse traits. Flavour brings out notes of cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, fruity accents, wet wood and oak. There is some sweetness to it as well, which is unexpected in the style; though despite the sweetness, its still quite dry in the mouthfeel. Medium-to-high carbonation, finishing on notes of wood and spices. Solid stuff, but I actually prefer the blonde version more so.

Pours a clear garnet color with a lofty tan head than falls to a thin layer. The smell is brown sugar, roasted malt, yeast. The taste is rich malty, brown sugar, some fruit ending a bit dry. Light/ medium body a bit slick with nice tingling carbonation. A nice complex malty brew.
Etwas muffiger, recht malziger Antrunk. Brotig, leichte Hefenoten. Das Bier wird weicher, rund, nett. Wenig hopfig. 8/9/7/9/8/10

Very complex subtle malt flavors. Layers of raisin bread, rum raisin, dried dark fruit, candied plums, milk chocolate, caramelized banana, honey, browned apple, light toffee and spices. Awesome mouthfeel. Fine, creamy carbonation. Medium-medium-light body. Rich flavors, without the extra weight. Super easy to drink. Belgian Dubbel like. Deserving of its acclaim. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
bottle offered at farmhouse fest. rich bready sweet dough. rustic fall leaves. good.
Sample at the HF saison fest, as simple and rustic as it comes, malty and rich, very traditional

750 ml bottle. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. An interesting nose of caramel and oxidation, fruit. The flavor is very nice: rich sweet notes, mellow slight sour oxidation, bready, berries, some light citrus. Very drinkable and good.

Orange-copper, hazy, off-white head. Aroma: lots of over-ripe fruit, doughy bread, berries. Flavor of grainy and toasty malt, some toffee, an oxidized, leathery note, fruity notes of peaches and pears, an earthy and musty note, low bitterness, malty balance.

poura a clear bright amber with a thin off white head...light sediment.  aroma has some cereal and mild honey.  flavor follows suit and steps up the honey...touch of earthy dry leaves.  mouthfeel is mediuma nd silky with a dry leaves/honey/grain finish.  tasty.
Bottle, rated from backlog. Clear dark brown with white head. Aroma with malts, yeast and some fruit or berries. Flavor with malts, hops some fruit notes, bitter finish.

pours clear light brown-reddish topped by a light beige head, some retention and lacing. caramel and herbs, light skunky and barn notes, fruity and spicy malts, earthy and spicy hops, some dirt. average carbonation, light body - very smooth and nice mouthfeel, dry herbal-grassy-earthy finish - very good balance too! but not very complex - plain rustic, linear yeast. did not particularly enjoyed that one - did actually DP it. 
this bottled brew would probably develop more skunkiness when cellared in its green bottle - which is not consistent with a bière de garde..

Bottle shared by czar, thanks! Pours a reddish brown with a nice whit head that leaves heavy lacing. Aroma is a bit skunky with a bit of malt sweetness. Taste is more of the same: malty with old hops showing through. Mouthfeel was nice and smooth. Enjoyable for sure, this is a style I need to drink more of!

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by czar, thanks! Clear amber with a medium diminishing off-white head and some lacing. Aroma of caramel, light fruity notes and light skunky presence. Taste is moderately sweet with fruity notes, nuts and malt. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Not very complex, but really well-balanced.

750ml bottle 6,5% ABV, 25/05/13. Pours auburn with a medium-sized, beige head. Aroma is... underwhelming: Caramel and yeast. Not much else. Unfortunately the flavor follows the aroma. Not much there either. Caramel, dried fruit, some herbalness, light touch of yeast. Meh. The palate is a bit too light as well, not much carbonation.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Seriously massive never ending gusher here upon opening.  Pours extremely cloudy orange copper color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy off-white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big caramel, pear, apple, grape, honey, floral, herbal, clove, pepper, bread, and herbal earthiness.  Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt with fruity/spicy ester notes.  Taste of caramel, pear, apple, grape, honey, bread, floral, herbal, clove, pepper, and herbal earthiness.  Lingering notes of caramel, light fruits, honey, bread, floral, herbal, clove, pepper, and earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic balance and complexity of malt and fruity/spicy ester flavors with moderate hop earthiness; and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a fairly slick and moderately crisp mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent Biere de Garde style!  All around great balance and complexity of malt with fruity/spicy esters and hop flavors; and extremely smooth to drink.  A highly enjoyable offering.
Flaska från Systembolaget. Kopparfärgad vätska. Doft av bröd och små toner av bär och karamell. Beskedlig beska.

Bière ambrée pur malt. OK. Bière de garde, je naime pas trop, mais comme Bavay
est près de la frontière, on peut essayer... Fabrication artisanale à lancienne de la
famille Theillier.
Couleur ambre moyen, quasi brun clair. Clarté nette.
Bulles moyennes partout mais pas assez nombreuses.
Mousse beige clair qui tient à 1 cm, bien floconneuse.
Arômes de malt,candi brun avec touches de cassonade, pointe de noisette et pain
gris à lancienne.
1ère bouche à la texture douce et présentant un côté très original genre malt à whisky.
Arrière-bouche sur des céréales et un bon houblon plutôt fleuri.
2ème bouche toujours avec le même côté un peu fumé, et arrière-bouche équilibrée.
La 3ème bouche passe à un goût un peu plus neutre, et le rétro-nez est plutôt caramélisé.
La longueur reste sur le malt caramélisé qui ressort constamment (bière ambrée oblige ).
Levure inexistante. Alcool correct, pas mal progressif.
La finale noffre aucun élan, et on est même proche de linverse...
Bière avec de bons débuts donc, ensuite on stagne et on est à la limite de la descente en
finale. Aspect le plus négatif dune dégustation, comme chacun sait...
Donc, rien de grandiose, ni même de mémorable, sauf le petit côté malt à whisky.
Cette détestable habitude de la bière ambrée vient encore de nuire ici à une bière française,
et qui plus est, du Nord  Mais le débat est inutile.
Bottle 25 cl @ HBF 2013. POours dark brown copper color with big bubbly head. Strong notes of dark bread, sour dark bread and roasted malts. Not bad at all.

Bottle 25 cl, BBE 12/2013. Pours clear amber with a foamy tan head. Nutty aroma, some dark fruits and some bready malty notes as well are there. Dry. Bready malty taste, some dark fruits but just a little bit of them. Slightly bitter with them light fruity and bready maltyness in aftertaste.

(Bottle, 0.25 l, at HBF2013) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, yeast and berries. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, hops, boiled vegetables and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. Not an impressive brew.

250 ml bottle @ HBF2013. Pours an copper amber colour with a white head. Aroma of sweet malts, hay and bread. Flavour of sweet malts, hay, cardboard, grass and some lemon. Light bodied, slick mouthfeel and a fruity, cardboardy finish. Past its prime.

250ml bottle @ HBF 2013

Pours dark orange with a foamy head. Aroma of ripe fruits, malts, spices and yeast. Taste is smooth, yeasty and slightly fruity with notes of malts and spices. Finish is spicy and malty. Decent, but nothing special.

Sample @ HBF2013.
Pours copper color with a small head head. Aroma of grain and malts. Flavour of cardboard, malts and hay. A bit disappointing.

25 cl bottle @ HBF13, BBE 12/2013
Aroma is quite light with some toffee, grain and hay. Flavour is sweetish with grain, caramel and hints of hay. Also a malty and woody feeling here. Foamy and creamy palate. Good.
Smak och doft av plommon, russin, trä, blommig brittisk karaktär. Söt och en aning vattnig eftersmak. Lätt beska.

Light misty, glowing brown body with creamy head of light tan bubbles. Delocate aroma of caramel, lightly roasted chestnuts, a farmhouse yeast and red rind cheese. Although that sounds more complex than it is. Taste is also medium bitter with light candy sugar throughout. Flavourful, yes, but not a full, rich taste experience that I was hoping for (giving its ratings here on RB). Its good, especially well made, but I hoped for a smoother, richer, spicer and/or yeaster experience. (75cl bottle from Bière Révolution)

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2013 13/I/13 - 25cl bottle from Abbaye des Saveurs (Lille) @ Klaas place - BB: I/2013  (2013-18) 
Clear amber to orange beer, creamy smooth off-white to light beige head, pretty stable, adhesive, some small sediment floating around. Aroma: lots of caramel, bit sugary, banana, metallic, pretty spicy, peppery. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: quite some caramel, little sour touch, very fruity, red berries, ripe forest fruits, some strawberry jam, bit sugary, sweet malts. Aftertaste: soft bitterness, some orange peel, general fruitiness, canned peaches, little hoppy, caramel.

750ml capped.  Pours a dingy amber toffee brown with slight haze with floaties and a tan tinted loose head that reforms easily.  Very earthy green hay malt dominate, bready, hint of apple and cotton candy, bit more caramel shows as it opens up, faint nobel hops melded into the malt.  Bready light caramel sweetness, balanced low level hops that give that green hay bitter earthiness though out, but never is more dominant than malt some very faint apple/lemon notes as well.

Pour is amber, thin eggshell head that quickly dissipates. Toasted, caramel malt aroma. More light, sweet, biscuit malt follows in the flavour. Light bodied, fairly lively carbonation, smooth mouthfeel. Finish is biscuit with an edge of toffee. Simple, but nicely done.

Bottle, farmhouse label. Chesnut brown pour with off white head. Aroma is a bit off, tons of brown sugar, really sweet smelling, light cherry aroma as well. Taste is better, still lots of brown sugar but a bit more graininess that you would expect from a good biere de garde. Palate is still dry despite the perceived sweet flavors. Decent.
Znakomite piwo. Po pierwsze wygląd. Świetnie się nalewa z wielką pianą, piwo mało nagazowane, koloru bursztynu. Karmelowo goryczkowe z nutą syszonych śliwek. Etykieta w starym stylu. Polecam

Personally I thought it was interesting but I cant say that I would buy it again or that it was particularly tasty but I may be ignorant to the style. It was dark amber and smelled grainy. Taste was grainy amber belgian and reminded me of caracole amber. Overall, not bad but not impressed.

Sample @ SBWF 12. Amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is fruity, malty. Flavour is sweet, grape, honey.
Smakprov på SBWF12 Grumlig bärnstensfärgad öl med ett lätt smutsvitt skum. Doft av mörka och torkade frukter, jordgolv, jäst och lätt kryddighet. Malt, lätt pepprig jäst och frukt i smaken.

Sample at SBWF 2012.

A bit hazy amber with a small head. Sweet aroma and taste of fruit, toffee, orange, sugar and malt. Also notes of wood and berries. Nicely balanced and a pleasant beer to drink.

Light amber color.  Some cardboard and an old yeast character. Dry grain and bread dough. Well carbonated.   Light malt and unprocessed grain flavors. I wish there was more happening with some complexity.

750 ml bottle. Pours a very hazy amber with a small off-white head. Later pours yielded heavy yeast sediment. Really nice aroma of farmhouse funk, mixed fruits, sweet malts, grass and herbs, and bread. The flavor doesnt quite hold up in terms of smoothness or complexity, with notes of sweet malts, fruits, leaves, earth, and funk. Medium-bodied, with soft carbonation and a malty, spicy mouthfeel. Very good Biere de Garde.
Sample at ÖÖWF 2011. It poured a golden liquid with a white head. Fruity smell and taste with caramel, a bit wineous and complex. Very nice, specially the smell. Easy to drink.

Bärnstensfärgad med smutsvitt lågt skum. Stor ganska söt doft av apelsinblomma, kandissocker och sött mörkt bröd. Riktigt bra balans mellan rejäl alkoholfylld maltstomme med söta karmelltoner, lätt vinösa drag med lite körsbärsvin, tydlig humle med maskrosbeska och körsbärskärnadrag, liten fatkaraktär och ändå lättdrucken. Inga delar sticker ut men otroligt välavvägd.

0.75l bottle @6.8% from Saveur-Biere. Hazy brown colour, big off-white head. Aromatic and spicy hop aroma. Medium-bodied, good malty background, slightly grainy, very spicy and aromatic hops with a resiny-grassy and dusty touch. Smooth palate. A very well crafted Bièrede Garde.

2*250 ml bottles bought in a mixpack and shared at tasting. Pours hazy dark amber with a frothy and creamy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and tiny metallic with banana bread, dried dark sweet fruits, red grapes, cloves, allspice and hints of barnyard. Taste is sweet and malty with bread, caramel, plums, mandarin oranges, orange zest, toffee and hints of alcohol. Mouthfeel is round, tiny tart, tiny sticky sweet and medium bodied. finish is sweet and malty with bread, bread spices and prunes.

(Bottle) Pours deep orange brown with a creamy off-white head. The aroma holds clear tones of dark bread with undertones of fudge, milk chcolate, grass, herbs dew, mild phenols and minerals. The flavour is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of dark bread, fudge, caramel, grass and herbs. The mouthfeel is round, creamy and soft with a light carbonation. Medium bodied.

Bottle 25 cl, GIL. Pours clear mahogany with a creamy beige head. Aroma is malty perfume sweet fruity a bit soapy. Flavor is very malty bitter sweet spicy bitter bready and nutty. Finishes malty caramel bitter.
Bottle at Gott i Lådan, Billdal, 120421. Amber/golden beer, nice offwhite head. Malty bready aroma, yeast notes. Bready flavor, malty, some spices.
Sampled at Larsniclas testing. Pours amber with big light brown head. Smells nutty malty. Tastes sweet nutty malty with a similar finish.

25 cl bottle shared with gnoff, sampled on March 10, 2012

Hazy red-orange with yellow head.  Very sweet and spicy malty scent.  Caramel malt and sweet bready flavor.  Medium mouthfeel with a tart dry and nutty finish.

25 cl bottle via brekeriet (thanks to Nisse666!), sampled on March 10, 2012Clear brown color, small tan head. sweet, spicy scent. Mineral, dry, cream taste. Moussy mouthfeel, dry high bitterness. Dry bitter aftertaste.

Bottle 75cl @saveur-biere, a cloudy amber-orange beer with medium head and good lacing. Nose is sweet like and seems quite malty, some round caramel is there. Aroma is malty, grainy, with apricot notes, round hops especially at the finish that give a nice caramel / grainy note (similar to german unfiltered pilsner or kellebier), even toasted and light biscuit notes, fresh brown bread touch. Body is slightly fruity on apple and dry grapes with vanilla and spicy notes such a licorice and honey, very well balanced. Hops bouquet is nice too with a grassy / floral aroma and medium to high bitterness at the finish which is quite long. Im not sure its the best French beer but its a well done one, very pleasant and well aromatic, lovely, very long and powerful aftertaste.

Bottle from SB cons 2012-02-20
Ar: melas, roasted malt, wee yeastiness
Ap: amber colored body, 1 cm thick white wee bubbly head
F: fizzy, roasted malt, dry, sweet, nutty, medium bitterness, full bodied

Thanks mom!  Gusher. Violently carbonated.  Murky gold orange with one finger of crackling white head.  Nose shows major oxidation and acetaldehyde, bready and peppery with herbal grassy hops. Flavor is the same, very apply and oxidized. Cidery and herbal peppery notes.  Medium body and crisp carbonation.

Bottle picked up at Belmont Party Supply in Dayton a month or two back. Served in a Mikasa tulip.

Pours a copper-amber color with a two-finger off-white head with some great lacing and a thin collar throughout. The nose carries a good dosing of bread crust and amber malt. Slight caramel and earth. Slight bit of pepper. Flavor is quite similar, but a bit more tame and more toward the malt. Could use a bit more yeast. Medium chewy body with good carbonation. Quite nice, and far preferable to the Blonde.

(bottle) A big head built up as soon as I opened the bottle, and continued into the glass. Head is a light beige with a cloudy copper body. Aroma of hay and grass, yeast clean earth or clay (slightly metallic, but not in an off-putting way), with fruit notes, sour cherry. Medium to full bodied, creamy and carbonated. Some lacing on the glass. Buttery malt and yeasty flavor is similar to the aroma, but more pronounced fruit flavors: cherry again, slight orange. Pretty even and balanced, actually kind of refreshing.

Bottle. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy grassy aroma with hints of dark fruit. Fruity malty grassy toffee flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty grassy toffee finish.
Malty smell, clean taste, fresh carbonation. Extremely handsome beer, nothing sticks out, just perfectly balanced.

Fruit, malt, and some belgian-style yeast in the aroma.  Flavor is sweet and bready, with toffee, orange and spice.  Spicy bitterness and a little alcohol balance off the sweetness.  Never heard of this beer before, but I will look for more.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 8 Oct 2011) Amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Malty, fruity nose with notes of grainy malt, grass, orange and toffee. Malty, fruity taste with grain, dried fruit, cereal, caramel, orange and a slightly spicy bitterness. More than medium body, with a certain sweetness. Complex, tasty and quite nice.

750 ml. Gorgeous amber with a bit of small suspended solids, and a huge, sticky cover of cream. Aromas of spicy wood, citrus zest, old leather, grape must, oxidation and earthy spices. Sweetish tastes on front of grape must, apple peel. fig, cinnamon; then some earthy leaf, sourwood honey, beeswax, oxidation, and toasted pecan; all bittered very well by a light, pithy wooden note.  Medium body has low carbonation and is sweet-ish, but seems to have a lot of acidity and spice that dries everything quite nicely.
herbs, fruity, cherry, honneyamber, minimal head, clear, heavy cloying sweetness, roasty, full body,

Beautiful amber beer. Sweet aromas almost rum-like, dried fruits, hay and caramel. The body is light and the flavours are very flowery.
From a bottle at GBF 2011. Clear amber, medium off-white head. Grainy, sugary and spicy aroma. Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry to semi dry, medium bitterness. Way overrated.
Bottle. Special biére de garde. Big bodied. Very fruity. Lots of yeast. Some spices. Thick. Not very dry and therfore not very refreshing. Still very good though.

I feel like Im rating this beer quite high, but it really was that good I guess! Bottle from 2009. Pours a clear amber color with a good-sized khaki head that leaves some lacing. Aromas bursting of dried fruit, caramel and spices. Flavors of dark fruit (maybe fig?), spices, cereal and honey. Sweet and dry finish. Average carbonation. This is a unique Biere De Garde and I like it a lot.

75cl bottle from Lille.  Pours hazy unclear amber, with a thick head which relatively fast stays as a veil on top.  Perhaps the beer was served too cold as it is clearing as it is getting warmer. Never the less it is not a clear beer I have in front of me. The aroma is of caramelized malt, very similar of the aroma beer made with DME (dried malt extract) gets. No hint of hops in the nose.  The taste itself, though, is influenced by hops. Its malt, slight caramel, and bitterness from woody hops (Brewers Gold, I suspect). Its not balanced at all, and makes the taste experience quite strange.  The mouth is full with adequate carbonation.  Overall, it is a lovely rustic beer, but very different from other amber Biere de Garde I have tasted.  Their blond is better, IMO, but if this beer actually is made from pilsner malt only, receiving its color from a very long boil, I am impressed.  But the aroma and taste reminds me of beer made with DME.
On tap at Moeder Lambic F. Hazy dark amber with a huge head. Sweet, malty nose. Taste is wheat, malts and dark berries. Syrupy. But texture is quite light. Sweet finish.

Bottle @ home- another gusher. Amber appearance with a cream colored head. Caramel malty, light belgian yeasty nose. Sweet caramel malty, Belgian yeasty, slightly tangy, very malty flavor. Very caramel malty flavor. I enjoyed blonde considerably more though this wasnt bad.

Draft @ Moeder Lambic.
Ambrée, col épais beige.
Arôme procure au départ une note de grains de moutarde suivi ensuite par des agrumes; citron ainsi que un profile houblonné et côté ferme basse court.
En bouche, une bonne surprise, profile malté pale et cara avec un léger aspect grillé, le tout accompagné dune note houblonnée qui rajoute une touche de citron avec ce petit côté levure belge. Seul point négatif, sur la fin la bière gagne ce côté un peu lager qui gâche un peu le plaisir du début. Original car cette bière change en fonction de sa température et laisse entrevoir un profile différent selon létape de dégustation.
Bottle at Churchkey.  Cloudy brown, massive tan head, solid lacing.  Aroma of malt-o-meal.  Taste is very malty, pure cereal with oatmeal and brown soda bread.  Nice.

The beer is light murky gold with a nice white head.

The aroma is sweet hops.

The taste is very nice, its like drinking a champagne beer, lots of sweetness and carbonation.

Bottled 250ml. -Courtesy of and shared with Marko (thanks!)
Blue label as Blonde?! Clear amber coloured, small to medium sized off-white head, lively carbonation, malty caramel nose. Sweet malty, fruity and slight spicy with notes of caramel and pleasant hoppy finish. Nice surprise indeed. 6.5%

biere de gardes- still a mystery .. . pours a medium gold, decent foam, quite a bit of floaties .. . aroma of wood, earth, and day old showered french person .. . light and refreshing beer, more earth and some bread, pretty clean stuff .. i enjoyed this .. . Bottle thanks to jrob21 which I shared at the March BA Tasting.  Pours a clear amber with an off-white head.  Floaties noticeable.  Nose is of funk and barnyard.  Taste is the same funk and barnyard.  Somewhat like a lager in the taste.  Mouthfeel is medium.  Not my cup of tea.  Did not like much.

La Bavaisienne (blue label), 0.25l, 6.5%, claims to be Blonde, it obviously isnt. Dark amber body with a white head. Malty nose, caramel, orange, honey... whoa, subtle, sublime, lovely! Flowery honeyish sweet maltiness, balanced by a dry peppery hopiness. Caramel pops up but doesnt stick around for long. Rosemary again? Oooh yeah, this owns.

750 ml green blue foiled bottle

It pours a copper honey color with a large foamy off-white head. There are plenty of yeasty floaties to be seen. The head stiks nicely and recedes to some decent lacing.

It is skunked unfortunately. Reminds me of a Euro Pale Lager in the smell, skunky with some caramel.

The flavor is better though it is still a bit skunked. It has a nice caramel toffee flavor mixed with some basic malts. It is a basic amber beer.

I have to try it fresher/non light struck next time, hard when they insist on the green bottle.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-12-2011 23:45:25
Hazy amber pour with some crap floating around.  Good light tan head.  Grainy aroma with honey notes.  Dry honey and cereal flavor.  Bitter finish.  Nice and dry and easy to drink.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2011 Aroma is malty, clean, spicy, mild. Nice clear appearance, medium head. Well balanced and mild taste. Sparkling palate. Overall extraordinary good.
Amber with a lasting white head. Malty aroma mostly with caramel, some dried fruit and spicy yeast notes. Dry and malty flavour. Easy drinking at 7% ABV and a good classic Biere de Garde

Bouteille de 25cl, titrant à 6,5%. Belles couleurs automnales, une mousse très correcte. Une bière de garde dans le style de la fameuse jenlain ambrée, cependant moins caramélisée et de ce fait un peu plus amère. Se boit bien au cours dun repas notamment. Trouvée au cellier des arcades - Arras

Bouteille de 25 cl de LEmpire du Malt à Clermont-Ferrand (F). Ambrée nuageuse, tant pour la mousse que le liquide. Nez profond de malt, caramel, houblon. La bouche révèle une bière de caractère, riche, ferme et corpulente. Ni trop douce, ni trop sèche, elle reste légère en bouche, avec des notes de pain, épices, terre et houblon. Bière de Garde à lancienne, avec cette différence qui fait référence.

750mL. Pours a clear light amber with lots of yeast floaties and a thin, white head with excellent sheety, white lace. Aroma of red grapes, cherries, musty yeast, slight corn and raw grain. First whiff is extremely sweet malty and dark fruits that hints at what will be a sweet, cloying, Belgian strong. But the taste is very neutral, all malt, very soft, doughy, yeasty, slight fruitiness. Pretty basic. Excellent soft, velvety palate. Slightest tartness and red apple skins come trough eventually.

Bottle. Low fluffy whit and quickly disappearing head. Clear amber golden body. Mild fruity aroma with hay and malt. Powerful fullbodied dry dusty fruity flavor with low carbonation and a long sweet aftertaste.

750mL bottle smuggled out of France by my folks, cheers!  6.5% ABV.  Pours clear gold/amber with a persistent, compact off-white head that leaves some lacing.  Very floral and somewhat fruity hop aroma, a little malt and yeast.  The flavour is clean and crisp, mild bitterness, there is a fruitiness from the hops and mild malty sweetness.  Light-medium body, average carbonation, fairly creamy with a long drying finish.
Slightly cloudy amber pour, fluffy off-white head.  Fruit, hay, caramel, some sweetness and biscuit.  Decent.
caramel, chocolate, coffee, toast, herbs, amber, clear, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, average carbonation,

Bottle. DØE Tasting, French beer. Pours a clear and copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt and sweetness. The flavor follows the nose closely. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer with a good balance.
Pours amber with a large off-white head. Aroma is caramel, fruity notes and light grassy hop. Flavour is caramel, light alcohol, fruity notes and light grassy hop.

Amber beer with a moderately sized off-white head. From the nose of this, this has to be a BdG brewed with lager yeast, just the tiniest bit of sulfur, but it doesnt detract in anyway. Lots of big chewy malts in the nose some burnt sugars, a hint of corn, plenty of green grapes and a touch of herbal hops. The flavor is light to moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lots of doughy, hay-like and musty yeast, golden raisins, grassy hops and a touch of apple. Expertly conditioned; this is stuff is like silk in my mouth, carbonation is represented, but gentle. Finish is just a tad tart, lightly bitter and refreshing. Hells yeah, great BdG.

750 ml bottle; thanks to Beerlando for the trade; pours muddy light brown with thin, creamy white head lingering; lemons, honey, husky wheat and oats; some orangey fruits too mixed with slight spice; wow, what a killer beer; drinks with a fizzy mouthfeel and delicate mix of dried flowers, honey, oats and wheat; a little nutty with lemon grass and dry spicy malt; light and sessionable, but at the same time its a very complex flavor profile with lots of yeast and texture; absolutely dynamite and I need more ASAP

Bottle @ YNWA, Kolding.
Pours clear redish amber with a fine, small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has red apples, fat malts sweetness, a hint of metal and red currants. Medium carbonation, great dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is soft, caramel, some toffee, grassy, a hint of metal and cardboard. Great peppery feel to it and a long, lingering bitter finish. Nice.
Toasty caramel malty, earth and fruity taste. Ok hop flavor in the aftertaste and bitterness. Bottle.

Bottle at Torben Mathews tasting. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Nice candis notes. Moderate bitter light sweet flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, hops and perfume.

Bottle thanks to Beerlando!Transparent light-mahogany, thick white head like a cloud. Nose is salty nut, some grassy hop, and light lemon. Flavor has the similar nut tone, more hop, light spice, and some rich malt through the finish. The body is large enough and well balanced, nicely muted yet showing a very lengthy finish. I like this one save for the off nut notes.

This has been and continues to be one of my all time favs. Pours with nice foamy frothy light tan head that mostly settles down and not much lace (this time). Aroma is yeast malt a little hop spice. Flavors like aroma and I pick up a short sour tang in the front. And then again just a bit at the end. Body is excellent with carbonation that perfectly compliments the rest of the beer. Satisfying yet very easy drinking. Session.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez moi. Arôme: Odeur de caramel fruité avec une pointe dépices. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée légèrement voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel fruité avec une pointe dépices et de pommes. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #2936)

Not the better french beer but asolid one.   
Toasty caramel malts, earthy and fruity yeast. 

Great hop flavor in the aftertaste which brings bitterness. Nice

Despite his lack of complexity a sure value. This is a rustic beer with a strong caramelization and long bitter finish. Not the greatest french brew, not a sophisticate one, but a solid and powerful beverage.

750ml bottle, at least one year old.  Pours a lightly hazy, reddish-amber color with a small, foamy tan head.  Sticky bands of lacing coat the glass well.  The aroma is simultaneously sweet and earthy, showing initial notes of caramel, bread, fig, and dark raisin, followed by earthy, bretty yeast and hints of old, moldy wood.  Flavors are similar, very much fig and raisin driven, yet caramelized and bready as well.  Its quite earthy, showing hints of must, old wood, and peppery, dusty yeast.  Semi-dry and slightly prickly on the tongue, the palate is sufficient, but unexciting.  Overall its a decent brew, but the heavy fig influence and weird woody thing just doesnt do it for me.

In short: A mega-rustic amber Ale with a strong barnyard character.   An acquired taste
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed when 6+ months of age.  One of the many bottles sent to me by MrChopin, thanks a lot Kevin
The look: Cloudy golden blonde body topped by a medium beige head
In long: True barnyard nose, dirty, cheesy, wet fur, musty.  Taste is very yeasty, earthy, ripe banana peels, leather, old wood barrel, whole-wheat bread, apricots, graham cookies.  The beer is also quite hoppy with plenty of leafy hops with a tobacco leaves character.  Oily sensation.  Medium dry, very mild bitterness, light-medium acidity.  One of the most rustic barnyard beer Ive had.  The beer is not very tasty, I could have done without the acidity (didnt work here) but overall this is a very complex beer.  This is a very nice brew.  Im afraid that the French will one day brew the best beer in the world, the one thing they dont brag about.
Colore ambrato.Schiuma bianca,abbondante,spumosa e persistente. Aroma ottimo di luppolo. Buon corpo maltato, con lungo e aromatico finale, in cui dolcezza e luppolo si alternano. Grande.

Name: La Bavaisienne Amber
Date: October 28, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Rare Beer Club
Appearance: hazy amber, fine off white head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet fruity aroma, lots of fruity esters, light spicyness
Flavor: rich fruity flavor, sweet esters, light balancing spicyness
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4

750 ml. Big, frothy, off-white head, long lasting. The body is cloudy amber. Aroma of caramel, cookie, flowers, mustiness with notes of peach, orange and earthiness. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet, lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. The caramel notes remind me of an English ESB. Nice dry bitterness in the finish that overtakes the sweet caramel and fruit. Clean, easy drinking. Solid.
Well carbonated dark copper-amber. Big head. Light clean nose; light earth and spice with a faint fish scent. Earthy caramel and base metal flavour. Lots of caramel in the finish and aftertaste.

750 ml bottle poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of toasted malt, fruittiness and spice. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of toasted malt, apple, pear and spice with a crisp dry fruity finish.
Bottle, amber orange with good tight foam, aroma is grainy metallic, flavor of some fruit and grainy sweet finish

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of malts, honey, grains, light hops, and light yeast.  Poured orange/deep amber in color with a small, loose, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of cocoa, malts, grains, light yeast, slight caramel, slight honey, light hops, some earthiness, and some toasting.  Medium body.  Chalky texture.  Average carbonation.  Sweet, malt, grain, and slight yeast finish is chalky.

750 ml bottle.  Musty, funky aromas, malty caramel, with a spiciness on the nose.  Pours golden amber with a thick white head.  Good funky malty flavors, caramelly, spicy, musty flavors, very earthy, pumperknickle bread, finishes with a malty sweetness with just a hint of tartness in the end.

750 ml corked and caged bottle purchased at Zipps in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Pour is lighter cordovan mostly towards the ruby end, topped with a nicely formed 2 inch off white head. Pretty lacing left behind as the head falls slowly. Aroma is softly sweet (brown sugar) maltiness and nice grass earthiness. Some initial skunk on the pour, that clears quickly. Very gentle nose, inviting. Taste is the nose, soft brown sugar and slight burnt caramel sweetness of the malt and the yeast characteristics of grass and earth. Nice melding, very smooth beer. Palate is low carbonation, medium bodied with a pleasant residual sweet finish. Probably the nicest Bière de Garde I have tasted.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 75cl bottle.  Something about this theoretically dull beer hits the spot every time.  Straightforward, slightly caramelled, pur malt,  honest, clean and beery.  The label on mine bears no relation to that shown, which I guess is the exported version.  Maybe the better quality is a local availability thing.

Bottle via a trade with tytoanderso. Pours with a clear orange body and a fluffy bone colored head. Aroma of corn, light funk, grass, caramel, pepper, butter and some fruit.Taste is straw, grassy, bready and caramel. Medium carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. Not the best BdG I have ever had.

Shared by BMAN1113VR
Appearance:  Pours a fairly clear amber orange with a thick stripe of white suds.

Aroma:  Light funk, mulch, stagnant water.

Taste: Caramel and burnt sugar right off the bat. Some earthiness, some funk and finishes on the dry side.

Mouthfeel: Soft and almost creamy.

Overall: Non-offensive, not that memorable. Thanks for letting me try Andrew.

Bottle. Pours copper amber with a thin head. Sweet bready malt aroma with toast, toffee, and a light herbal note. The flavor is malty sweet and toasty, with a hint of toffee and a dry earthy/herbal finish. Nice.

Bottle from Premier Gourmet, thabks for the recomendation Ethan. Pours an amber color with fluffy white head. Medium carbonations. Malty nose with some saison like spice & yeast character.Taste was bready, dry, toasted malts, some sweet malts, lightly spiced. Almost like a lighter Maudite in taste profile. Very good

From jrob21 via trade.  The pour was amber and clear with some bubbles racing upwards towards an off-white head that produced average lacing.  The aroma was lightly toasted malts, caramel and light citrus hops.  The flavor was toasted malt, some citrus and a bit of sugary, caramel sweetness.  Relatively thin body with a dry mouthfeel.  A pretty simple beer.  I could see this as this regions version of a table wine.

750mL bottle.  Label is slightly different than that in the picture.  Pours a clear amber with a HUGE antique white head that leaves chunks of lacing.  The funky aroma features plenty of biscuity maltiness, grapefruits, some toasty caramel, and a lemony graininess.  Thin to medium-bodied.  Some toasty caramel, biscuity malts, and graininess start things off taste-wise.  Finishes crisply with some sour lemons and a bit of drying grapefruitiness.  Decent balance.  Solid brew.  Drinkable, but boring style.

750ml bottle, again from tyler......pours a medium amber brown with a thin soapy white head...aroma of light grassy hops and biscuity caramel malt    flavors of some biscuity malt, semi bitter and a lightly hopped character. finish somewhat on a slight bitter note

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2009 750 ml Bottle. Copper color, huge foamy off-white head and LOTS of sediments floating around. Malty aroma with hints of grass. Similar taste enhanced by some caramel and more hoppy notes. VEey nice.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Thanks!  Pours dark amber with a beige head.  SMell is funky and light caramel.  Taste is watery, light caramel.  Not much going on here flavorwise.  Medium body and high carbonation.  Decent, but boring.
Pours cloudy caramel color with light tan head. Aromas of toasted malts and caramel. Toasty, nutty flavor with a slight sweetness and a dry, earthy finish. Medium body with mild carbonation.

(25cl bottle) Hazy, dark amber coloured hue with yeast chunks and a big and beige foamy head. Sweet and toasted malty aroma with caramel and delicate fruity notes, accompanied by cinnamon spice and draff. Sweet flavour with a touch of burnt bitterness, medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Draffy, toast-malty taste with a restrained fruit-character and spicy accents; medium-dry, slightly toasty and moderately sweet finish with a lasting caramelly aftertaste. A good but not a great one (11.08.08).

Rating 1000!  Bottle from sams in Durham, NC  Hazy gold pour with a fizzy white head and excellent lace.  Citric aroma. Complex flavors consisting of citrus, bread, malts, honey, toast, and earthiness.   A long bitter dry finish

750ml from Sam’s, Durham. Really pricey at $17 but probably the best biere de garde I’ve had. Whereas some examples of this style can be a tad too sweet, this lovely beer manages to incorporate a wide range of flavors - some sweet malts, fruitbread, a hint of caramel - without at all compromising the farmhouse funk and zesty yeast/citrus/spice finish that I really enjoy. Very balanced, well integrated throughout. Wonderful stuff.

750mL bottle.  Pours a hazy, golden-orange color; off-white head with good retention and lacing; lots of particulates near the bottom of the bottle.  Nicely toasty, citrusy aroma: mild acidity, toasty malts, and honeyed sweetness; strikes a very nice, enticing balance in the nose.  Good, very drinkable levels of carbonation.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of citrus, toasted malts, crackers, and honeyed sweetness upfront; intensely drinkable, nicely dry, with plenty of honey and sweet maltiness while still being crisp.  Beautiful rendition.  Lengthy finish: honey, crackers, and toastiness; nicely dry.

Bottle.  Pours light brownish/amber color with a bubbly off-white head.  Some fruity sweetness and earthy notes in the aroma.  Medium bodied.  Slight sour notes and some fruit in the flavor, with some malt and yeast.  Somewhat crisp and rather refreshing.

Malty, bitter and refreshing... reminded me of an Altbier for obvious reasons. 25 cL bottle at Delirium pours a dark, reddish copper, with a nice beige head that fades. Malty, sweetish, grainy nose with dry hoppy notes. Flavor has a light, caramel sweetness, carrying into a dry, raspy, moderate bitterness. Finishes dry with a hoppy aftertaste. Really nice.

(3/10/08) 25cl bottle at Delirium Cafe in Brussels. As La Bavaisienne Ambree. The label on the bottle looks like the one on La Bavaisienne Blonde just with blue instead of red. Best before 10/06. Deep amber with floaties and a medium off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel and some ftuirs. Great malty flavor, rather sweet but with some drier tones  caramel,  bread, some toastiness and some hoppy notes. Finishes dry. Medium-bodied. Quite simple but very good.
750, capped. Thanks, after4ever! Pours orange-amber with a lacy off-white head. No lace. Mild nutty/funky nose. Medium body, subdued carbonation. Caramel, spice and a touch of funk in the taste.

Nice, but a touch heavier and more caramelized than I expected. Not that such is a drawback. Deep copper color, huge foamy head that was pretty uncontrollable. Herb and caramel aromas and flavors. Nearly candyish. Mild but indistinct spicy hop notes in the finish. Highly carbonated.

750 ml bottle, relatively fresh.

Pours a golden orange with a fluffy white head and lots of floaty gelatinous material (think Abbaye Des Rocs). Gently earthy, grassy, hop-spicy aromas. The flavor shines. Lovely orange, not c-hop resiny but just nice citrus from the melding of hops, spicy yeast, and a gently sweet malt. Slightly peppery, not as much funk/mustiness/dust as Id expected. Very easy drinking, deeply enjoyable beer.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a very large sized head of foamy fine to large sized off-white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a hazy with with a huge amount of floating yeast chunks in a typically carbonated yellow colored body. The aroma was musty and dark malt. The mouth feel was smooth at the start and mediumly tingly at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of malt hops and coriander. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

750, capped. Thanks, Boboski! Pours a cloudy dark amber with dense and moussy but fairly thin tan head. No lace. Mild nutty nose. Medium fizzy body. Lemon and chocolate notes on the mid-palate, and quite predominantly, which are a complete shock for the style, but then again nothings really surpring with this brewer. Long herbal finish. Good, enigmatic stuff.

Wow, this paired perfectly with thanksgiving dinner.  Nice cloudy golden color with a big fizzy white head. The spicy, citrus and hop aroma complemented all of the aromas from the food we were eating.  The flavor was smooth, full bodied, slightly carbonated, and slightly sweet.  Very enjoyable.  Extra points for the experience as well.

750 champagne type bottle poured into tulip glass... Lively amber beer topped with firm off-white head.  Aroma of soft malt with evidence of some melanoidins.  Toasty and lightly earthy., very light aroma of hops cuts malt aroma... Flavor explodes with soft yet full malt flavor which fades into a rich malt finish, medium toasty, somewhat bock-like but residual sweetness is cut with a slight spicy note that is complemented by the high carbonation level.  Initial spice character augmented by carbonic acidity , but disipates as carbonation deminishes.  Mouthfeel is medium high to high and carbonation level lightens feel on tongue.  Residual maltiness provides pleasant finish.  Nice beer, would go well with a rich dinner, hey, maybe turkey!
user_location: Port Jefferson Station, New York, USA

text: hazy brown with a big frothy head. yeasty bready aroma with some nice spice and earthyness. flavor is malty with spicey yeast and a touch of dank and musty hay. medium mouthfeel with a great balanced finish. great balance throughout and a pleasure to drink. been a favorite of mine lately.

750, about a year old. Pours with a great, huge pillowy head. Aroma of roasted almonds, chestnuts, violet and fresh herbs. Lots of herbs in the taste, old hops, minty yeast. Very balanced, and a superb drinker. Very nice BdG that would likely pair well with a very wide range of food.

Bottle courtesy of Turdfurgeson: Poured a deep slightly hazy brown color ale with huge white foamy head with some good retention and some good lacing. Taste of deep malt with some balance sweetness and some spicy yeast. Body is full with some great carbonation and no alcohol could be detected. Lots of character with a nice creamy body. The balance in this beer is just incredible. I would love to try this again.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Nice cloudy-amber pour with a pillowy, off-white head.  Aroma is very bready with some nice spice/earth tones and some subtle fruit.  Flavor is a bready-earthy mix with a nice helping of earth and light citrus hops.  Lots of tasty spice and pepper that contribute, along with a good hop helping, to a really nice mouthfeel.  Tasty brew that I will definitely be buying more of.

750 ML bottle, 7/2/07:  Hazy medium amber w/a lasting thick, creamy, off white head.  Earthy & musty w/ peppery & spicy, dusty yeast aromas.  Grainy pils malt and a light herbal hop.  Flavor is herbal hops, peppery/spicy yeast, but hop dominant.  Pils malt flavor is light.  Earhty overall flavor w/a dry finish.  Lightly bitter aftertaste w/ herbal hop flavor.  A bit one dimensional actually flavorwise.  lighter body due to high carbonation, and a dry m/f w/ well hidden alcohol.  This one may need more aging, but it seems a bit light on the complexity scale for a biere de garde.  Not a bad beer, maybe its just my mind, or at least what I think a biere de garde should be.   Also goes well w/ shrimp & rice pilaf.

A powdery body of rust orange hue.  Dynamic nose.  A heavy stink of horseblanket and farmhouse hay.  Brown spices.  Green apples with cinnamon and sugar.  Sweetness warms into French toast and syrup.  Taste lacks a similar evolution.  Feels dirty and dry.  Earth, wet leaves, and a hint of dark honey.  Band-aid and cardboard.  Dry licks of clove and ground anise toward the finish, where a subtle maple sweetness slowly blossoms.  The barrel casts an imposing shadow, but this provides little nuance beyond the wet wood.  Yeast lends a generally musty disposition and is thick enough to be somewhat unsettling.  Full and rich texture.  Certainly unique.  Thanks Andy!

Pours a relatively clear amber with a big off white head.  Smells of malts, caramel, a little candy sugar, and some spice.  The taste is a little the same.  Pretty malty, almost syrupy, good dose of some cinnamon and caramel.  A little bit sour and funky, finishes smooth with some of that biere de garde flavor too it.  Definitely an intriguing and complex brew.  I can see why its rated so highly.

25 oz bottle, Stateline Liquors.  Pours a dark gold body under a one finger fizzy foamy white head.  Tons of chunkie floaties churning about.  The aroma is very funky and dry, classic for the style from what Ive had.  Light wheat and hay with a undertone of slightly fruity and doughy malt.  The flavor is equally funky with lots of yeast influence.  Finishes with notes of grassiness, yeast, alcohol, and a touch of pepper.  Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with lots of fizzy prickly carbonation.  Overall, this was pretty good, and an especially good example of the style to me.  The chunkies were a little excessive, but better than being totally filtered like some BdGs.

Pours a beautiful amber body and a tall creamy white head. The aroma and flavor bring sweet caramel malts a hint of rustic yeastiness, a wet bale of hay or straw, candy sugars, rich moist nutrient rich compost dirt, chestnuts, black pepper corns, and a soft hint of clove. The palate is silky with its velvety carbonation A very well made beer, but a tad too sweet for my palate.

Bottle from boboski, thanks jerk.   Rating # 1000!  The aroma is a blend of grass and caramel malt.  Golden body with a huge off-white head.  Medium palate.  The taste is quite complex.  I find aspects of malt, grass, yeast, chocolate? and some light spices (pepper).  More malty than I expected, but easy to drink. Much better as it warmed up.

(750 ml bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>CaptainCougar, thanks Tom!) Pours cloudy light amber with a big, frothy, rocky off-white head that sticks around for awhile. Aroma of bread dough, vanilla, yeast and spice. Mouthfeel smooth, light but fairly full. Globby, foamy bits of lacing. Flavor is light malty, bready, yeasty with light pepperiness in finish. Quite nice but gets even better as it warms/and or deeper into bottle. Butterscotch merges with the light pepper and swirls around with the bread dough, yeast and vanilla. Light peppery aftertaste. Quite enjoyable. This unique style is really growing on me even after just two!

Cloudy golden brown, huge head rocky random head with great lacing and retention. Aroma is yeast, caramel, lesser notes of fruit and grassy hops. Very soft smooth mouthfeel, light sweetness. The only BDG so far that made me sit back and go whoa.

I am very surprised to see this beer so highly rated, as my experience with this beer was not all that positive.  I this beer had a handsome appearance but was otherwise pretty boring.  

The beer was an attractive red color with cumulus cloud head composed of consistently-sized tiny bubbles.  However, I detected no aroma at all.  Flavor-wise, I got some malty sweetness balanced with more hops than I expected (the one real redeeming feature of this beer).  Still, I ddint feel there was much flavor here.  Throw on a rather watery mouthfeel, and I am not much impressed.
Really nice beer, nice malt flavors, and just enough hops. almost like a ocketoberfest ale!
Hazy dark copper color with an unstoppable head.  Aroma is a bit metallic.  Flavor is filled with sweet malt and a twinge of hops at the end.
Aromas of malt, alcohol, and caramel.  Flavor is slightly sweet, malty, and very pleasant.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 750ml bottle. no date but rusted bottle cap. pours a beautiful hazy reddish orange with off-white head. nose is pretty funky, hay, grains, subtle smoke and caramel. really nice nose. flavor is caramelly, plums, pretty funky. carbonation is high and lively, actually fun to drink as it dances on the tonge. alcohol is well hidden. mouthfeel is full. body is medium. middle notes are soft caramelly sweet but it finishes very dry, crisp, and refreshing. this is nice on this hot spring night but would be bliss on a hot summer day.
Bottled (As ambree). Amber colour, huge beige/off-white head. Aroma is malts, yeast, caramel and some earthy notes. Flavour is quite the same. Fullbodied

Thanks to  Beerdrenched  for picking this highly rated Biere de Garde for me.  Pours lightly hazy copper with a huge beige head.  The aroma has toasted malt, dry caramel and hazelnuts.  Medium / full body with medium-sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with earthy caramel, various spices and some nuttiness.  The finish is fairly sour and sharp with an amber ale taste that stays around.  This just came across to me as an okay beer.  It is not dates, so either this is an old bottle or this just isnt my thing.

Amber color. Thick foamy head. Citrus aroma with a touch of caramel. Hopbitterm earthy citric flavor with touches of caramel and butterscotch. Pleasant beer, not world shocking, but tasty and an easy drinker.

750 from the Spirit Haus... gotta love living around the corner from a sick beer store.  Pour was cloudy dark amber into a tulip.  My stuffy nose from my allergies prevents me from getting the full aroma.  The mouthfeel is like an oily IIPA.  The flavs are rye bread, hops, grass, and citrus.  The hop flavor is like the hop rod rye... its strong, piney, and spicy.  The beer is refreshing as a saison or farmhouse ale should be... this was a delight to drink.

Dark orange colored, little yellow head. Sweet aroma with caramel, toffee, vinous touch, berries, mild alcohol and grains. Medium bodied, crispy palated. Flavor is also dominated by berries, grainy tones and drying hops. Still missing some character for having this near 4p average, for my taste.

Bottled 75cl as "Ambrée" (BB 05/2007)
Amber color, steady creamy off-white head. Grassy, woody hoppy nose. Grainy, dry and grassy flavor. Nothing is happening in this beer, its not bland bad but bland. Looks quite overrated.
Pours deep gold into a tulip.  Fluffy white head slowly recedes with spot lacing to skim surface.  Earth and citrus aromas.  Crisp and smooth with caramel and a lasting bitter hop finish. Very nice.

25.4 oz bottle.  Hazy orange brown with a lacy white head.  Lemon candies, hay, brown sugar and some funk.  Like a light barleywine in taste; sort of oily.  Caramel malts with sweet orange and grapefruit.  Crisp carb, light body, some sour in the finish.  Refreshing yet substantial.  A beauty!

No date on bottle.  Excellent pour, with nearly half head, creamy, off-white, but settles nicely to a moderate size for drinking; fully lasting and lacing is nice.  Body is a nice hazy, orangey, coppery, amber color.  Very nice nose with excellent toffee notes and rich caramel as the forefront; toasty notes, doughy yeast, and maybe plum back with a spicy, musty farm presence but quite subdued.  Flavor is more balanced between the rich, malty notes and the other flavors; notes include toffee, bready/doughy yeast, earthy/musty farm character, buttery notes, lightly nutty, fruits of peach and apple, and with a moderately light, but nicely balancing,  bitterness.  A sour note of sour apple flashes across the palate briefly.  Palate is lively, medium-full, somewhat quenching, and round in character with a silky smooth feel.  Finishes moderate length with some earthy notes and an almost chocolate note.  This being my first true version of the style, it was a little hard to rate; however, it was very nicely done and it was quite enjoyable and intriguing.  Fairly complex, nicely balanced, extremely drinkable, and very delicate in character.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2013 pours a rich caramel color with an enormous head that actually keeps growing in the glass.  huge floral, citrus, toffee, earthy, buttery almond aroma.  lots of lacing.  flavor is of toffee, butter, nuts, citrus, and hops.  what a surprise.  awesome beer.  4/1/07 

re-rate 4/3/13.  This bottle was purchased 6 years ago.  pours a lightly hazy amber with a small white head.  nose of paper bags and butter.  no mouthfeel.  the beer seems to disintegrate on the tongue like dust.   a buttery flavor with some caramel.  high carbonation.  weird.  hops are long gone but the original malts seem the same from what i remember.
Bottle from PP Belgian Beer Fest.  Honey on the aroma.  Nice malty and banlance flavor with a touch of unexpected bitterness in the finish.  A favoite of this style.

Bottle.  Pours hazy copper color with a thick, fluffy beige head.  Aromas of caramel, yeast, spice, musty and some dark fruits.  Flavor is not what I was expecting, not fruit at all, some smoke, tobacco, burnt caramel, chocolate, bitter coffee.  This was not what I was thinking it was going to be, kind of bock like.   Still it is easy going down.

Bottle. Copper colored beer with a huge beige head. Big caramel aroma with backing yeast. Earthy, yeasty, caramel flavor - farmhouse flavors with hay. Slight fruitiness. Musty. Bigger malt flavors, but theres still a huge yeast component. Medium body. Lasting earthy, yeast and caramel. Maybe a bit of roastiness, but definately nice and complex.

Pours nearly clear copper colored, quite effervescent with 2" of rocky cream colored foam. Good head retention and lacing. Lightly malty aroma.

A good and malty brew, with a mild caramel being the most prominent flavor. A trusted beer sage told me it reminded him of a good bock. I cant disagree. A touch of spicy hops in the finish.

Very clean and smooth - very lager like. Great carbonation.

out of the bottle. courtesy of a fellow beer drinker though not a beer rater. thought id give a shout out anyhow. pours a golden-orange-mohagany. smells of doughy yeast as well as caramel and some lighty fruity notes.  tastes is much bigger than expected from the aroma. peach, apples and spice - mouthfeel is full and round with the sweet malts and fruity hops. you can definetely taste the yeast and bready doughy tastes and even light hints of caramel and chocolate. its kind of earthy and dirt dry but smooth at the same time. I wish I was a more experienced beer drinker to fully explain the complexity of this interesting, drinkable, enjoyable beer. one to try people.
UPDATED: JUN 1, 2008 Bottle.  Sour milk and biscuit aroma.  Cloudy dark amber color with moderate head.  Sour  malt flavor but with strong metallic aftertaste.  Nice beer - flavors are subdued.

Poured deep amber with a head that took for-ev-er to dissipate.. just a wee bit overcarbonated.  Quite a complex flavor on this.. excellent bier de garde.  More hops than Im used to in a bier de garde, but the caramel flavors in it are quite unique and unusual.  Id like to buy a case of this and store it.. if it werent $10 a bottle.. oh sweet bliss. ;)

Color is an amber coloration with a thin cream colored head. Aroma is very floral, with a bit of caramel, almost some wheat like character to it also, a bit of espresso, but its light.  Taste initally is a light hop content, followed by a coffee, and chocolate sweetness.

750mL bottle purchased at Sams. Pour is a deep, cloudy, and hazy orange no doubt due to the unfiltered nature of this magical brew. Nose is earthy and grassy, with the typical yeast funk that follows many of these biere de gardes. I like it. Flavor is surprising. While its initially follows the nose with bready, yeasty funk, it immediately delves into flavors of rich, dark malts, coffee, light chocolate. My only issue is that the palate is a bit sweet, but the unique qualities of this beer make for a very enjoyable experience. Would like to try the yellow-capped blonde soon.
Listed on the bottle as Amber, it smells quite malty. A little caramel. Has a bit of funkiness or sourness. Earthy and sweet, but not too heavy.

(07.09.06) one pint, 9.4 oz brown bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 7% ABV. Sweet prune nose. Clear amber with large white head. Good carbonation. Medium bodied ale that starts with light malt sweetness and plum fruit and toasted malt flavors.  Finished with light bitterness and malt fade. Well-balanced and smooth. A delicious beer.
Pours a light amber with lots of floaties. Smells a bit of flowers. Very sweet and full. Tastes a bit of bubble gum. Hints of iron. Dry flowery finish.
Bottle. Golden to amber cloudy colour with a nice fizzy head. Aroma of heavy caramel and malt with a hints of sourness. Nice flavour of malt, caramel and with a full body finish.

Orange amber in colour, very large long lasting creamy white head, awesome lacing, lots of floaties.  The aroma was of caramel, light alcohol, light spice, cherries, citrus, bready.  The flavour is of caramel sweetness, quite malty, lots of spice, herbal, buttery, citrus.  very smooth creamy mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes with some light alcohol, long and malty.  Fantastic stuff, incredibly smooth.
750ml bottle from <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.  No Best Before date.
Unclear hazy amber colour, lots of sediments and a small off white head. Malty, caramel and alcohol sweet aroma with yeasty and fruity notes. Malty, sweet flavor with yeasty and fruity notes.

Bottled. I have rarely seen a more disgusting looking beer. Very hazy with loads of huge chunks everywhere. Even in the foam there is brown chunks. As expected from a beer with such an appearance the aroma is extremely yeasty. Some notes of rotten fruits. Extremely yeasty and cloyingly sweet flavour, again with some rotten fruit notes. Totally unbalanced and unclean. Undrinkable.
Bottled. Pours gunky and orange in colour with a medium sized head. Malty and sweet with notes of fruits and caramel.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2008 Lucid dark copper with a light tan head.  Very nice color.  Nose is barnyardy, lemon, grapefruit, apricot, and hay.  Carbonation is just right.  Crisp citrus gives way to raisin and stewed plum, then to toffee and coffee with the hops. A little bit of toasted almond too. I love the way the complexity of the flavors roll from front to back.  This ale gives a faint sweet impression but is dry overall with good hopping.    Absolutely beautiful.
Bottle Thanks to CMUBEERMAN. Pours golden orange with super white head. Aroma is grass, hops, musty, bitter. Flavor is grass, hops, wheat, citronella.

Bottle.  Pours amber with a frothy off-white head that diminishes a little over time.  Aroma is fruity (orange, pear), malt (meal, cereal), yeast (grass, earth) and a perfume nose.  Moderate acidity and bitterness, yeast and malt balanced body that yields to the floral and citrus rind hops, tart finish.  Medium bodied and fizzy, dry palate.  It mellows as it warms.
Bottle. Amber colour with a small tan head. Sweet malty, fruity, light spicy aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.

(Bottle 75 cl) Amber golden with lots of ufos and a small, creamy, off-white head. Fruity aroma. Medium body with sweetish, fruity accents. No real bitterness. The highest rated French beer?? That can only be because its exported to the US. Theres much better stuff around guys... 061006

Bottled. Thanks to Probiere for the trade. Amber coloured. Unclear. Light brown. Loads of sediment is disturbing the looks. Aroam of sweetness and fruits. Spices and light sourness is detectable. Flavour is light earthy and sour. Has some fruitnotes and spices and caramels are present. Medium bodied. Ends on a sweet and spiced note. Nice one.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with lots of floaties and an off white head.
Aroma of fruits, spices, caramel and dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of dried fruits, caramel, spices and fruits.

An orange beer with a lot of sediment floating around underneath a disappearing orange head. The aroma is sweet spicy - with cinnamon being most dominant. The flavor is also sweet spicy with strong notes of cinnamon.

copper pour w/ a tall fluffy white head thickly laced.  Lightly funky aroma some floral hops a good amount of sweetness some earthy notes.  Palate is nicely coated and kind of fluffy.  Flavor is lightly sweet tangy carmels & sugars some bread notes some fruits a light spice.  Pretty good.

Pours to the best looking beer ever.  A huge sexy foamy/frothy/creamy coolwhip like light beige head that lurches out of the glass.  Gorgeous lacing.  A nice dark brassy copper body.  Nice visible carbonation.  The aroma is lemongrass, sweet malt, light cement basement, some brown malts.  The flavor starts off as sweet yeast and fruits with some lemons, then morphs into a sweet brown ale-like body, then the late finish has some interesting chocolate malt.  Hints of lemongrass and other garden herbs with light nuts and dry grassy hops.  So delicately balanced.  The palate starts creamy up front and then dries out significantly leaving the mouth watering for more.

Huge light tan head. Lots of bubbles coming up in the bright, clear copper body. Light dry chocolate malt with some astringent hop hints, possibly from the head. Aroma turns nicer the more I wait. Dry earthy chocolate, light grassy hop character, light fruit. Very delicate. Interesting light flavor too. Very dry with a bitter dry grass component blended with cocoa powder, grainy fruit. Very nice and interesting. Dry cut grass burps.
"Hmmmm i loved this beer. Poured an amber with massive head with amazing lacing. Aroma was citrusy and spices. Flavor was muc hteh same was a little sweet. Aour in the aftertaste."

Faint champagne apple malts dance from the heavy carbonation of this beaut. Really not getting too much aroma though. Pour of beautiful fired amber, with a rocky ivory head. Flavor is a ridiculous amalgam of sweet full grain flavors, like Ive rarely experienced. Theres a variety of farm-like sweet candy grains and full rounds of light fruits. The malts are especially syrupy feeling, but the beer is in no way cloying. Instead, a gentle swashing of freshly roasted grain husks and tawny edges of apple brandy. Its damn delicious for sure. The yeast character seems subdued to a bready faint existence, despite the omnipresent appearance in the bottle. A smidge of hop dust in the backend draw balanced. I guess overall, Im dissapointed by the lack of aroma, but extremely satisfied with the skillful and delicate malting of this beer. It reaches German standards and is a beer that really lets these malty nuances stand and shout for themselves. Smoother than hell, too.  I could see how people might think this is bland, but they might not have refined palates. Thanks Clark!

Draught Clear foxy-amber-orange, with a very consistent (N²?) dense, amber-tinted head, leaving lace. Extremely timid nose, with a bit of garden herbs, notably parsley or chevril; toasted. Soft sweet taste, extremely malty, as just warm-kilned malt. Soft malty MF with grist slickness. Nowhere bad, but again, the draught version is not quite as well-lagered and exceptional as the 75cl.

Bottle from somewhere, dont even remember.  This is rated 3.95? wow.  I must confess, i thought this beer sucked and it was a horrible mess.  My bottle wasnt bad, as I picked up most of the other qualities mentioned in previous ratings.  I drank about half a glass of this and poured the rest into my yard.  Points for looking good, nice thick head on it, and the slight hoppy smell.  Taste was bad, and it reminded me of just a normal american lager.  Nothing special, and certainly nowhere near its 11.00 price tag.

Botle from Super Saver.  Hazy copper pour with fluffy, 3-finger off-white head.  Aroma of floral spices, bready malt, citrus, and hops.  Tastes bready malty, floral, spicy, and fruity, with some mid-palate earthy and cacao notes.  Very complex palate.
Poured from 750 ml.  Explosive carbonation, head formed as if I were pouring a Duvel.  Subtle grapefruit aroma and upfront malty charecter.  Quite quenishing with a a great hop balance
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of citrus, alcohol, and spices. Flavor is spicey, citrusy, bitter. I hate this style, i didnt care for this beer.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours amber\copper with a large off-white head. Aroma of citrus, alcohol, spices, and caramel malts. Flavor is spicey, sweet, citrusy, alcohol present, hgood hoppy bite. Good body, good brew.

From a gold top, blue foil wrapped capped 750 ml. green bottle with a blurb on the back label, no bottled/freshness date, sampled at a cooler cellar temperature in a chalice.

Poured a cloudy with sediment dirty copper with a foamy beige head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing.

Aromas of toasted caramel malts, coriander and hop spiciness, an earthy yeastiness, a slight musty, but fruity wheat malts, mainly apples and ripen grapes and small whiffs of alcohol.

Good carbonation and a crisp, smooth light bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious tasting, toasted caramel and sweet apple musty bread, an dry earthy, chalky yeastiness, a nice spiciness from the hop with hints of grassiness, towards the end a little cedar wood comes out, and a dry yeasty, grainy finish. The alcohol is not that noticeable, but provides a slow warmth in the palate. This has a very good drinkability, almost too quaffable.

A tasty French/Belgium ale, well worth seeking out and trying.

Orangey copper, with a sizey white head. Woodsy, earthy aroma, with notes of mushroom, maybe? Smooth, viscous plate. Subltle flavors of smoke, pepper, and rich malts, as well as some winey, tart notes.  As it warms, sweeter notes of caramel and honey and molasses emerge, but never overpower. Very well made, and a perfect compliment to grilled pork chops.

750ml - thanks Secret Santa Dec 05 (JPDipso) - Aroma is yeasty, spicy, and a bit funky.  Pours cloudy brown-orange with a huge fluffy head and great lacing.  Flavor is sweet and a bit more subtle than aroma and not nearly as funky as I expected.  Palate is sour and sticky.  Very tasty.

After a so-so experience with their blonde, I was quite impressed with this one - highly carbonated, burnt copper pour, with a lightly tart, bready aroma - flavor is biscuity, with a mellow tartness, balanced by a gentle, toasty bread flavor - light fruity esters and a semi-dry finish - very subtle - very tasty.

I doublt that this beer is very old since I just bought it last week as soon as it came into my favorite beer store, and the label is different from that shown here.  Nonetheless, this "aging beer" is still quite good.  Big, foamy off-white head over a dark orange-hued body.  Yeasty and mildly malty aroma - some herbal qualties, and some floral notes as well.  Not too sweet at all - slightly heathered with some light honey.  This is a nice lighter beer for the hot summer season.  Ill be buying more if I can find it.

Holy smokes, the French can do beer too? I was pleasantly surprised by this one - somewhat of a cross between a Belgian saison and golden strong ale. Poured with a humungous, frothy and pillowy head (no vigorous pour required!) and lacing that formed thick rings around the glass. Mouthfeel was thick with definite carbonation. Color was cloudy amber with sediment galore (which I enjoy). The aroma was slightly spicy with some orange-citrus tones. The flavor definitely revealed a sweet, orange-flowery base with a bitter-sour balance to the finish.

750 ml bottle, generously sent by slob in trade!  Pours a beautiful amber color, clear except for the plentiful floaties, huge fluffy white head and lots of thick lace.  Sweet and bready aroma with apple juice, delicate spice, light citrus notes, hints of earth and wood.  Delicious flavor, fruity and bready malts, gently tart in a floral, herbal and spicy way, a bit of orange and citrus in the finish.  Medium body, very smooth with creamy carbonation.  Liked this one a lot!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2006  Le Bavaisienne Ambree, bottle 25cl. Delirium cafe, Brussel. O.K. this one is just as hoppy as an i.p.a., but doesnt smell like that.  Very malty brew with a good bitter finish. Tastes also very fruity(pineapple, citrussy) and resinous. Wow, good beer!

A mostly diminishing average creamy white head tops up a clear medium amber body. Moderate lacing. No particles. Few medium bubbles. Aroma presents malt being medium caramel while hops are moderate grass ... Yeast character is moderate fruitiness. Also, there are evident evocations of spices. Initial flavor is medium sweet . Finish is medium . medium to full body... oily texture... Soft carbonation...

[ Bottled ; chilled ; dates are unknown ]

This Biere de Garde pours a medium, transparent amber/orange with a soft white head.  The nose is musky and lightly salty but strongly floral and somewhat fruity sweet.  The first impression of the taste is that the malts are "dirty" and Denver-esque (perhaps this is yeast), but this is replaced by stong caramel-sweet hints and then the lightest hop presence in the end --some dryness and a light bitter.  That is all to say that this is above average for the style, but it is certainly over-rated at nearly a 4!
Poured amber with a large fluffy off-white head.  Aroma of heavy spices and grassy hops.  Taste is light with a mix of some sweetness and some nice complex spiciness.  Fizzy body.

750ml. bottle thanks to Dickinsonbeer. 
Murky orange/amber color with a good sized off white head. Really nice funky,
floral aroma with some caramel and lots of yeast. Sweet, bready flavor with some caramel, wet hay and a stale cardboardy finish. I just wished the flavor matched the aroma a bit more.

From a bottle into a snifter. Beer poured a firey, hazy medium copper color with an off-white, frothy, mostly lasting head that left behind delicate lacing. The aroma has won me over to this style: The malt is sweet, vivid, smooth and clean with heavy notes of toasted grain,  and caramel. Some miscellaneous trace notes of spice and dried stone fruit. No hops, and just a trace yeast note of cellar to ground the sweetness. The flavor is well balanced and infinitly drinkablemoderately sweet and moderately bitter with an average-length, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is creamy and the carbonation is lively. No alcohol burn anywhere to be found. Im going to drink this all evening while I clean house and start trying to take back some of the nasty things I said about French beer after my first three samples of the style.

Pour is hazy orange amber with a skin of dense white head...some big floaties...smell is dates and very musty and yeasty...flavor is a little sweet and biscuity up front turning even more breadlike...the finish wrapped up quickly and was surprisingly bitter...

750-shared with whaleman.  pours chunky amber with a huge fizzy off-white head.  lightly funky, flowery, lightly sulferic, woodsy, spicy hop notes and some lemon esters emerge from my glass.  kind of a crazy aroma.  sweet, malty, sugary and metallic flavors (earthy hop presence).  this beer is pretty complex.  medium body with some tingle on the tongue after the sip.  some leafy notes in the flavors as well (mint).  the funky notes become more clear as the beer warmed a bit.  cool beer, but really not something i would seek out again.

this beer is great.  crisp and complex.
availability seems to be near nil.
im told the brewers all are terminally ill or something and have a hard time keeping up production as of 12/05.

Dull orange-amber body with a thick, foamy, just off-white head and a motley load of chunky particles and flakes. Aroma of dark organic honey, pine nuts, maple, and sweet wort. Wild, distinct and organic flavor with some pedio-funkiness and woodsy hop character. Medium-high sweetness with substantial bitterness and a fizzy, somewhat worty palate. Although this beer lost a unanimous decision in a head-to-head matchup with Jolly Pumpkin La Roja, Im happy that my long quest for La Bavaisienne has come to an end. Thanks TannerTavernboy Eric!

I was a bit worried to see a tad bit of rust present near the bottle cap when I took off the paper covering. I opened the bottle and everything seemed okay. The nose was musty, mostly grassy with somewhat of a caramel undertone. It poured fairly hazy, what looked like a yellow and amber infused liquid with a core of darker brown. A nice head was produced and soon dissapated. I was floored when I took my first drink...there wasnt much taste. It wasnt a bad taste, or an off taste. Just a lack of taste. Im ratign it a bit low, but will revisit it to ensure I got a good bottle.

750 mL bottle.  Poured a nice shiny medium orange with a 3/4" creamy beige head.  This was carefully poured... and there is a lot of sludge in the bottle, so I am rating appearance on first impression.  Very welcoming aroma of honeysuckle, caramel, hay, and a little must, with undertones of citrus, dried flowers, and spice.  Very pleasant caramel and honey base for the wonderful floral hop bouquet, lemon zest, fresh biscuits, and so much more that I cant place... in the flavor.  Heavenly smooth on the palate... malty sweetness through the middle, followed by lightly bitter lemon zest through the finish.  Finish was long and calculated, allowing a wonderful reflection on the beauty that was this beer.

I wouldve given this more points for appearance, nice brownish-amber body with a rocky off-white head, but there were to many yeast chunks floating through the brew.
