The aroma is swet caramel with floral hops and some vague spicing.  Medium bodied.  The flavor is a light caramel with honey, coriander, flower pedals, some citric zest, and a smidgeon of hoppy bitterness.  The finish is softly sweet, a bit spicey, and leaves a powdery coating on the tongue.  Im wondering if this bottle is off.  Most of the other raters see this as something special.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Mostly translucent and bright orange with some yeasties underneath an icy white sheen for the head.  Aroma is a farmhouse anthem: baguettes, lavender, lilacs, lemon grass, honey suckle, mellowed orange rind, coriander, lemon zest... it just keeps going.  Brisk and bright floral hops flavor.  Caramel, sourdough and coriander scratch the surface.  Musky hard water profile.  Lavender pairs with a husky earthen quality.  Hints of souring lemon peel intermingles with a mixture of cornmeal and honey.  Stagnant, and a boldly premature palate press from the effervescence, finishing staunchly, bready and boldly, with an aftertaste of rosemary dinner rolls.  Nuances abound.

Bottle 1 Years aged...

Aroma:cooked vegetable "ok i know its ok for the style"...
Appearance:Orange with a lot of chunk of yeast,good head...
Flavor:Caramel,cooked vegetable,alcohol......
Pours gold with a decent white head.   Some nice grassey notes are present on the nose.  Tastes of honey and maple sugar with a nice breaddy finish.

750 ml bottle into Aventinus glass.  Purchased somewhere in the Denver area.  There was some brown crust around the cap which made me a bit worried about the beer, but I dont think it was infected, since it was dope (or, if it was infected, then I liked this particular cocktail of bacteria).  Medium to large fizzy foam head of a peach hue sits atop an amber orange transluscent beer displaying visible carbonation.  The head mostly diminishes to a thick dusting on top.  Lacing has varied bubble size from uber-tiny to medium-small, quite a big difference even though none of them get large, and its brittle and sudsy, crumbling away quickly.  Malty warm soggy orange peel smell accents a mostly peaches-and-cream aroma.  Theres also some toasted sourdough bread in the aroma.  Very malty mouth, like a gran cru Belgian strong, with a flavor echo of the peaches and cream smell.  This is a very deft blend of soft feel and flavor with intensity, like a warm soft bed in the moments right after you wake up but havent opened your eyes, that feeling that is so tangible and all-encompassing in its gentleness and niceness.  Theres a lemon cream pie flavor in the beginning of the finish with just the hint of creamy acidity, and some nutmeg and other spices that I dont know to give it character.  Incredibly dope beer that Id love to have again.

Light beer with a permanent big fluffy head. Spicy aroma and taste. Not all that drinkable, and thin-medium mouthfeel. Pepper, cloves, cardomaon, grassiness and hops there. Best of France, whatever that should mean. Still drinkable at end of hot summer day. Better with food.

Bottle at The Moan and Dove. Hazy golden color with yeast in suspension, thin white head. Amazing aroma of spices, yeast, fruits and barnyard. Amazing flavor of fruits (apples), yeast, barnyard and spices. The body is light to medium with a dry mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Excellent, mind-blowing beer, its insanely well-balanced and complex, every elements fit and stick together as a team.

Hazy medium-orange body with plenty of particulates, puffy light tan head with brown speckles.  Earthy, peppery hops aroma with biscuits and toasted malts.  Unique flavor profile, peppery with slight metallic notes, plenty of herbal tea-like hops, and slightly sweet toasty biscuity malts.  After sampling nearly 1100 beers, I cant say Ive tried anything quite like this.  Complex, medium-bodied, and tightly carbonated, this unique beer is certainly worth searching for.  Thanks to hellomynameis for the trade!
A dark golden color with a white foamy head when poured from the bottle.  Aromas of hops, front lawn grass, and spices.  Taste is lightly bitter and of cloves and other spices.

750ml bottle: Deep amber, mostly clear, filled with medium-large sized particles suspended, large eggshell colored head.  The aroma is like a musty butter to start, then opens into mild honey-covered malt, grass, bitter stale hops & lemon infused honey, sweet oats, malt, orange rind.  Taste is very quickly spicy (noble) hops, then sweet light/medium malts, which are slightly syrupy-sweet, and sweet citrus (orange & lemon rind).  Theres a hint of alcohol towards the middle, but its something you really have to work to find in the flavor.  Mostly I just get sweet, butter malt & grass.  Moderate-lively carbonation that is quite easygoing on the tongue, medium bodied, and slick.  Finishes sweet and crisp, with hints of honey, grain, and grassy hops.

Bottled. Dark amber, lively head. Buttery malt aroma, Its well hopped with notes of grass, but its dominating feature is the soft, full, buttery malt character. It finishes with balanced, salty bitterness. A gem amongst French beers!

Thin head, glowing orange. Musty, sweet aroma laden with alcohol and sugar, orange peel. Taste is malty and sweet, fruity. Finish is oak, slightly dry. Medium to heavy body. A very fine beer, yet not quite agressive enough for me. Still good.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2006 Couleur ambrée, examinant avec enthousiasme la dense formation dune mousse blanchâtre et ultra-persistante.  Levuré, donnant un ton métallique aux arômes qui réussissent brillement à nous transporter dans la brasserie même.  À caractère très malté; foin, grains, empattage et doux caramel.  Finale légèrement oxydé rappelant les cennes noires fatigués.  Bouteille Moan And Dove 21 Mai 2005.  Merci Daniel!

I have been looking forward to this one- biere de garde is not a style that I am very familiar with, although is broadly similar to Ommegangs Hennepin with which I am very familiar. This pours a frothy amber that produces the paerfect head that lasts and lasts, forming that little mountain of foam in the middle of the glass looking just like whipped egg whites. The aroma is rich with malt, fruit and subtle hops. The moutfeel is very smooth and the flavor balanced with slightly sweet malt flavors melding with fruity yeast esters and a balanced finish, neither too dry nor too sweet.

Excellent tufty white head. Lots of little floaties in suspension in the body of this beer. Impressive aroma: very fruity with a peach pie element. Flavor is even fruitier, with a classic bread (not bready in the sense that its usually used on this site) element in the malts used. Hops appear and manifest themselves in the stunningly smooth finish. This is a commendable product -- yet another "mirror to the past" from that great beer-producing part of the world. Perhaps the best beer I have ever had from a ... GREEN bottle!

Pours a reddish caramel with a huge white head. Aroma is of light cider, mild melon, and a slight hay, and a mild cardboard that detracted a bit. Flavor is of caramel, mild cider, mild tea, and soft floral slightly grassy hops. Everything about the flavor is soft. Even with this softness it is still flavorful and satisfying.

Very dry in both aroma and palate.  Citrusy and floral, but slightly acidic.  Mild metallic notes were detected with the first few sips and the alcohol is only noticed with the warming effect that it produces.  Quite carbonated at first, but it mellowed after it had a chance to warm, very crisp and refreshing.

This orange colored farmhouse ale pours with a large fluffy tan head, eliciting a light hoppy aroma. The initial taste is slightly bitter with a fruity finish.  The flavor is very hearty and satisfying.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2007 750mL Blue label bottle sampled 2/19/05 with Mkobes and Maibockaddict.  Pours a brilliant, burnished copper-brass, with deep amber-auburn hues, a very hazy, unfiltered/bottle conditioned body and plentiful tan-specked-white head.  Aroma of deep, rich, earthy hay, lightly cheesy, old hops and loads of yeast funk.  As funky and unique as the aroma was, the flavor is what won me over with this beer.  It starts out with a hugely yeast/cheesey, dough-like flavor, similar to the aroma, with tons of rich honey-wheat-like bread and malt flavor, rich malt sweetness and lightly drying yeast towards the finish.  Caramel, sticky toffee and buttercream all grace the palate as well.  Full body and a  rich flavor that is unrelenting to the last drop.  Low, natural carbonation.  Perhaps just a shade too sweet, but its hard to critique this one.  Fantastic, and a step up in complexity and flavor from my previous favorite (St. Sylvestre Biere nouvelle)  8/5/10/4/19Early-to-mid 2006, 750mL bottle drunk on 11/3/07With about a year and a half of time in the cellar, I dont think this one got any better.  Much less sweeter than I remember it from the last imported batch, and still that farmy, though not funky, character to the yeast.  Not bottle conditioned, but still an immense, long-lasting and fully lacing head.  Unfiltered, however, and you can certainly tell from the texture, which is mostly soft and with some spritziness from the active carbonation.The flavor is both musty and woody, with moderate amounts of minerals and very gentle acidity on the end.  Low bitterness, not surprisingly, at this point, though I dont know if this stuff is that hoppy when fresh.  Musty, but very interesting aroma and a flavor that is full of sweet, chewy graham crackers and sweet dough, with honey and light apples.  Great stuff, with no sign of alcohol and a high drinkability.  Didnt blow me away like it did last time, but its certainly a very stylish beer.  Current score is from this bottle.

Beautiful reddish orange in color with a small and mostly diminishing head of white cream.  Aroma is mostly malt accented with hints of toffee, caramel and fruit along with a touch of hops (flowers). Initially on the front palate, the flavors are fairly mellow and tame, until the mid-palate explodes with fresh fruit and dripping honey and caramel.  Layers of velvety flavors.  A work of art as far as Biere De Gardes go.

amber color with yeast particles and fizzy in the center.  off white massive head that turns very rocky with strong overhang lacing.  malty straw nose, yeasty funkiness.  light sour aroma too.  dry yeasty, malty flavor, white grape too.  sparkly carbonation and creamy mouthfeel.  crisp hop finish with a light spice nip.

Malty nose with bubblegum, golden color (somehow darker than I thought it would be), lovely off-white dense head.  Good malty quality, carmelly with a long light bitterness.  Very dry.  Well done in a simple way, but a bit unexciting on the palate. (2004 Christmas Party, my #8, groups #9T)
Bottle.  A reddish golden color with a laced tan head.  A light dusty aroma, smooth and subtle flavors.  A delicate spice.  Christmas Party 2004 ranked 7/15 (mine) and 9/15 (group).

Wow, this one was a gusher, I lost about 15% of the beer.  Pours a darker, cidery amber with a whopping rocky, creamy tan head.  Aroma has a slight gueuze-y sourness and a good deal of yeastiness.  Flavor is very nice, notes of apples and spice, with some bold maltiness and a dry, hoppy, bitter finish.  I randomly grabbed this, never having heard of it, and got a delightful surprise.  Very good beer.

The deep amber body is topped by a voluminous whipped custard head that clings to the glass for dear life. This is perhaps the maltiest of the style that Ive had to date with rich caramel malts providing the base of the aroma and flavor. Theres a good bit of apple peel fruitiness and the flavor is a tad sweet. The only thing that bugs me about the beers is a slight harshness in the lingering bitterness of the finish. But the bitterness seems to fade as I drink it, so it could have been something to do with the temperature. Definitely gets better as it warms.

This is likely truer to style than Southampton, but must say that after having theirs that as nice as this is, it was a disappointment. Maltier, darker, fuller. Nice and full bodied and pleasant with a lovely head and all - spicey, creamy and quiete enjoyable.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy orange-amber body with a large beige head.  Aroma of earth and mustiness.  Creamy, soft mouthfeel.  Flavor of yeast, bread, grapes, and spices.

Nice amber brown w/thick white head. Malt, hops, light fruit, vanilla and a pislner-esque aroma rise from the glass. Med-Heavey weight with sweet mid palate and a lingering finish. Honey malt, light molasses, hops, and light toast flavors.  Very Nice!

Sharp, citrusy, earthy, lightly fruity yet spicy aroma balances carefully between sweets, fruits and spices. A different nuance is revealed with each inhalation. Beautiful deep copper coloured body with lots of visible tiny bubbles and strong tan head that lasts throughout and sticks to the glass. Earthy caramel with dark fruit tones and hints of apples blend nicely with the spicy notes and the perfect balancing bitterness toward the finish. Beautiful soft palate with gentle bubbles and medium-light body is a celebration on the tongue. Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2012 Great orange-amber body. Eternally lasting 1-inch foam. Very deep aroma although never aggressive. Makes you feels like youre the one who is lucky to study it and not the subject that is lucky to be studied. You are lucky to smell this and must offer proper efforts to grasp that terrific rusty character that is hard to pinpoint, but offers such a subtle earthiness to compensate those wet hay flavours and mild hops that seems to have a german origin as unlikely as it is (styrians?). Rather complex when you dig it with the perfect level of sweetness. Palate is a killer, just the right yeast character, perfectly peaking through the copious rustic flavours (basement, hay, wet cask wood, must etc.) Very dry finish, malty. Delicious, one that has you sucking your tongue afterwards. Highly drinkable, splendid spongy texture, foamy, hiding its high carbonation through an unreal quaffability I must concur with the general opinion that this thrones the bière de garde styleBig props to JPDipso!  I confess I find it a little sweeter than before and slightly less deep in yeastiness. A top BdG, but more of a 4.2-4.3 than a 4.5. I changed my mind again. The last two bottled I drank hit the spot flawlessly. Perfect earthy, deep yeast character pairing extremely well with the sweetish, full bready, gently toasty malts. Adorable and unique balance yet one that varies from bottle to bottle, but always remaining good, a bit like De Dolle or Fantôme in its best years. Rather phenolic/spicy for the genre and this adds another layer of complexity. Very drinkable with its 7% ABV remaining not felt at all. Really, thats pretty much perfect in its style.

Orange-amber with nice white head and some lace. Aroma of hops, spice, and malt-a little grassy. Flavor is biscuit malt  with a little sweetness and spice, balanced with some hops. The alcohol is noticable in the finish.

Smells damn good.  58F.  Beautiful walnut color.  Little fuzz on top doesnt hang around to long. Rich malt aroma with side notes of hay.  Yummy bread flavor with the thinnest spread of homemade currant jelly.    A bit of chewing gum,  some fresh alfalfa strands, and grass.  Ill tell you what, I could drink buckets of this.

Bottle pours a deep copper color with a monster meringue head and lots of lace.  It looks perfect.  The aroma is spicy.  The flavor is sweet, malty, yeasty, some hops, some spice, and very nice with a fairly rich body while being good and cleansing.  This is very smooth and hides the 7% ABV rather well.  Overall, this is the best in style Ive had.  I will stock up.  Thanks Ryan at Cellars!

750ml bottle:  Sampled at the CTRiver Brewers Festival.  This one poured an orangish-golden color.  There wasnt a lot of head on it.  The aroma was quite nice.  There was floral notes, as well as some fruits and spiciness.  The taste is very complex, and has a dryness and spiciness to it.  Really an excellent beer!

Smells like a lager. Huge, off-white head; billowy like a German hefe. Beautiful, reddish amber in color. Lots of visible carbonation and lots of particalia. Very well balanced. Maltiness pervades but with enough alcohol and hops to counter. Session quality if not for the relatively high alcohol. The best rated beer in France, but far from the best beer Ive ever had. I probably wouldnt buy it again, but it is good.
RBSG 2004.  Clear dark orange, malty corn and bread crusts and a gritty bread flavor.  Slight sour spices as well.  Medium bodied, refreshing, but with some strange peanut flavors mixed in as well.
Deep golden in color with a nice white head. Cheesy hops, Really nice tasting. Very nice malty background. Well balanced beer. Enjoyable.  Smooth.

Deep golden, nice white head. Aroma of aged cheesey hops. Saaz? Real nice. Flavor is rather hoppy, with the cheesey notes coming through. Nice bitterness. Nice malt backbone. Smooth. Enjoyable. And a new favorite.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Spicy herb garden outside barnyard yeasty funk aromas - you just want to keep your nose in the glass for this one.  Deep golden, slightly hazy, big head, great lacing.  Great malts - sweet apple-butter honey bread, smooth, sticky.  Ends with some lingering sweetness.

Dark Amber Coloring.  Frothy Head.  Very Floral...Grassy... Vegetables....Herbs...  Taste is Very Similar...Has some Spice to it...tastes a little peppery to me.   Havent Had alot of Biere de Gardes...and I dont think its something I would drink often, but I can see having a taste for it from time to time.  Very Good Overall.

Medium orange color. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is barnyard. Leather and must. A medium bodied biere De Garde. Malts are fruity and funky. Earthy and bready. Kind of sweet. Nicely balanced. Very nice beer. Smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Copper color with a medium head.  Aroma is heavy on a field smell: flowers, grass.  The taste reminded me of Kohlrabi (a vegetable).  Very spicy, but not in a peppery kind of way.  More grass.  I would definitely drink this again, but not very often and certainly only in the summer.

Pours a pretty, clear, copper color.  It is well carbonated and supports a prodigious tan head.  The aroma is sharp and spicy with some herbal notes as well as some malty ones too.  The aroma is a good marriage between malt, hops, and yeast aromatics.  My first impression of the taste is that this definitely hits the spot.  It is light and flavorful, perfect for a hot summer evening.  This has some nice sharp spicy notes that hit the front of my tongue; these are a nice balance to the malty sweetness that is also found in this beer.  The malty sweetness has a depth of flavor, which really contributes to the overall character of this beer.  I get flavor notes that are spicy, herbal, sweet and a certain caramel maltiness.  While I would be hesitant to call this a stellar beer, the integrated flavors really meld very well together.  This is certainly a well crafted beer, and one which I highly recommend.
Bottle.  Amber, big head.  Barnyard-blanket kind of a smell that I really liked, but the taste was a bit flat.
Pours a nice orange/amber, very translucient with tiny bubbles and a white head that leaves some nice lacing. Very fruity, malty taste, with some caramel, earthy and bready.

Really beautiful in the glass, bright, brilliant clear amber with a huge chunky, puffy head.  Nose mildly funky and grassy, noticeable yeasts.  Very bready and yeasts, has a rich, buttery character to it. Yeasty and a bit spicy, a bit like a tripel with some barnyard in it.
Brewtopia 2004:  Clear orange with a huge rocky head.  Spicy aroma with yeasty character.  Fizzy mouthfeel, medium bodied.  Ends slightly sweet and spicy.

Honey-butter, pepper (light), big head diminishing, golden-copper color, very deep and translucent.  Taste: supper nutty!  Peanuts...cashews, aftertaste of hops.  Slight butter flavor, slight crystallized sweetness.  Something indescribable that is a great pleasure.  Oakes says something about this beer being a lesson in malt extraction....ooh I would have to agree.  Layers upon layers.  This is sublime.  Where can I get more?

Golden amber with a small white head.  Upon sniffing my thought was of baby spring greens and salad vegetables.  Mouthfeel was medium, velvety, good carbonation.  Flavor was earthy, herbal, some spice.  Interesting beer.

Bottle. Very nice stuff. Starts off malty and toasty, with a subtle wheat flavour. Finishes off very farmy, savoury and herbal. Hay, dirt, horseblanket, earthy hops. Slight smoky edge. Orange rind and spicey hops to finish, savoury, this is a really good beer.

I cant be too sure that I am rating the correct beer here but that little lable in the corner (right) looks right to me. The head is white and lasting. The nose is malty up front with some wheat. The taste has got this strange taste to it. Imagine pulling a banch off of a tree, now taste the green of the inside of the branch. That is just about it, sour with kinda.

Bottle Brewtopia 04
This pours a light amber with a frothy head.  Complex malty aroma with touches of bready yeast, some sourness and an overall mustiness. The flavor gives way to a slight sourness with some malt in the background. Pleasantly different to be sure.

Hay and bread malt (M); leather yeast profile (L); honey, cinnamon?, butter aromas.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter, astringent finish.  Distinct pecan taste.  Medium body, oily/watery texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: Im nutty enough for the both of usI dont need my beer to be.

Brewtopia04.  Smells sweet, cugary, and cherry-ish with some musty old fruit.  A pile of sweet maltiness dumps from the glass and splashes down all over the palate.  Sweetness yields to sour and bitter.  What a lovely find on the Shelton Bros table at the fest, not an everyday beer, to be sure.  Its not so Belgian yeasty as man French beers tend to be, but it IS quite peppery.  Wonderful.

This beer was sampled at the San Diego Real Ale Festival thanks to Dr. Bills vast collection. This beer poured a brownish/orange/copper mix with a thick foamy tan colored head that refused to go away. The aroma had definite hints of aging, with lemon, flowers and citrusy mango in the nose. It almost had a lambic-like sourness in the nose...very hard to describe, heavily acetic. The taste begins with a frontal malt assault complete with roasty toffee and finishes with an astringent and tongue numbing lemony citrus. Light roasts then return and lead to hints of vanilla in the finish. Very earthy beer I must say... a strange balance between sweet and sour, but a very complex and cool journey I must say. Dry finish, but sweet after the initial sour burst. Another must try again!

Pours a deep copper body with a efferevescent tan head. Looks almost like a champagne or sparkling cider. Aroma is odd. Sort of caramel, flowers, and fruit. Very light aroma, though. Taste is flowery with some roasted notes and some sweetened malts. Palate is almost overwhelmed by the resounding fizziness, but its a lighter feeling that expected. I guess due to the smaller conecntration of bubbles. Finish is a bit sweet but theres a lingering bitterness. Damn good beer! I can see why this is the number one Biere de Garde!

Pours a dark orange colro with a small white head and minimial lacing.  Aroma has the fresh brewing beer smell.  Musty, toffee, and citrus.  Flavor is toasty, caramel and butter.  A musty sourness leads to a medium finish.

Clear amber with a big rocky light tan head. Very nice malt slightly sour citrus musty aroma. Toasted toffee, bitter cocoa are followed by musty sour malt, yum-yum! Beautiful body,   medium dry finish. This is a really nice beer, my expectations were very high and this beer exceeded them.

The beer after divorcing the 750ml green bottle settles in the glass a bright clear amber color, the head is Bunyanesque in size, the texture semi-creamy, as it slowly erodes, and the lace forms a thick and sticky blanket to seal off the glass from view. Nose is somewhat sweet, a tad earthy and maybe a hint of over ripe apples to seal off the nose, start is lightly sweet with a nice malt presence, the top fair to middling in its feel. Finish is light to moderate in carbonation, with a spicy hop presence and the aftertaste quite dry and long lasting. As you pour each glass, the head pops right up to the top of the glass, a very interesting brew and my thanks once again goes to Argo0.

aromas of cookie like malts, must and orangy hops. golden color with some haze and a thin lace covering the surface of the beer. malty, cookies, bread, floral hop flavors and a bitterness that balances the malt in the finish. slight citrus flavors. cewey texture but still fairly dry. not as fruity as the saisons across the border. delicious chewey beer. tatses substantial but easily drinkable.

Nice looking amber beer with a massive off white head that is nicely retained.  Aroma is light apple juice and an aged aroma and leather.  Flavor is highly estery with perfume and floral charachteristics.  Very unique beer, I like it, but not passionately.

Sparkling copper, large frothy off white head.  Aroma was a tough one, but I basically got some earthy, leathery, cobweb type notes.  Not the best aroma, but the flavor is where this beer stands out.  Still hard to describe, but I got lots of fruity esters, a hint of caramel malt, and some citric hops to round it out.  Interesting and quite complex as it warmed.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, very dry finish.  A great one that needs to be tried by all....

This beer rocks!
Sparkling clear, burnt orange ale with a large, frothy, off-white head. Great retention with cascading lacework. Very earthy, musty aroma with notes of mildew and leather... not entirely pleasing to the olfactory system. The flavor more than makes up for that. Malty, fruity, hoppy, terrifically balanced. Full-bodied with lively carbonation. Lengthy, bone-dry finish. World class beer!

Mahogany pour with a nice creamy head and sheet lacing. Clear. High carbonation levels. A beauty. Wet malt aromas some crystal malts, with a nice mellow hop profile. Small spices abundant with a slightly sour note. Malt dominates the flavor though the hops sneak in there. A bit nutty. Hops seem mostly earthy. High malt character sticky palate and a bitter finish.

Oaky amber color, not completely clear, just a lite haze. Just like a haze of fog in a small french village, a piller of smoke coming from the chimney of a small cottage. Just like the bubbles in this chimay glass. The head is creamy; permanently thick & creamy with lots of retention and lacing. The aroma is lightly malty. A breeze of sweetness with some crisp hops riding in the wind like pollen in a field. Lots of caramel with a slight note of my friend Brett[anomyces]. The flavor is very spicy with lots of hop bitterness. The malts are cowering in the corner while the sweet & bitter duke it out. The tart carbination is the referee, watching over the battle. This is all taking place in an old barn, probably housing horses due to the barny overtones. Very good with just a bit of alcohol showing. Many thanks to BBB63 for this gem!

White head. Clear orange/red colour. Has a very ripe farmhouse aroma. Begins malty with touches of carmel and chocolate, but develops into a dry finish with a bold leafy/grassy flavor. Complex and interesting.

Hazy light copper with large tan head.  Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, fresh-baked bread, light vinous.  Taste is honey medium sweet, herbal, caramel, toasty/biscuit, some grape/vinous, peach, earthy.  Smooth medium body that belies the complexity contained therein.  What a wonderful beer!

Clear copper colored with a large rocky white head. Toasty,malty, caramel aroma with the slightest hint of barnyard. Malty with a subtle sweetness, dry in the middle hints of funk and ripe fruit, finishes fairly bitter.

No date on it, but maybe 2 years old.  Bought from John's Grocery in Iowa City.  I cleaned them out. Deep amber, nice head, great lacing. Aroma of MALT, background come the hops, bit of oxidation? or is that Brett?...just enough to act as a "highlight".  Massively malty beer with firm bitterness, refined for a hick(farmhouse) beer!! not bitter, but balanced maybe just barely towards it.  That bit of funk/oxidation comes back at the finish, then is overwhelmed by malt and hops and an interesting herbal?? yeastiness?? Great modified malt flavor, melanoidin/carmel flavors are fabulous.  This is something I could drink forever and ever.  I think it would make a perfect thanksgiving beer(for USA folks) with oven baked turkey and stuffing...dunno why

Seriously folks, buy this beer, drink it, and love it. Wow. Fiery amber color, huge white head that hung around for the entire glass. Strong aroma, hops, wine, barnyard funk, fruits and honey. Palate is incredible, the carbonation is soothing. The fullness of its body tops all other bieres de garde, and dominates any wine I've ever had (not that we should be comparing here). I can't even describe the complexity of the malts in this, just beautiful, rich and almost creamy, dough and bread; somewhat dry finish. C'est fantastique! Bottle found at Julio's Liquors in Westboro (go there).

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2006 Aroma is fruity, but more subdued. A distinct metallic quality to it. Caramel sweetness, sugar, pears, carbonic acid. Appearance is dark copper amber clear with light lacing off-white head.  Palate is medium watery with medium-high carbonation. Smooth, fruity, sweet up front, light acidity. Finish is much drier and more bitter, like a nice tripel. Belgian yeasty taste, musky. After is nutty, light bitter. This seems to be aged more, its mellowed quite a bit and the fruitness has subdued for more dry, bitter quality. Very nice. (7,4,8,4,16)
A nice beligan type ale-not a style I'm very familiar with, but a nice solid beer.  Not too funky or unusual-not much in the way of esters or anything.  Interesting though..

Copper color with a nice fluffy off white head atop my snifter and also some lacing.  Sweet aroma of grassy hops, malt, and citrus.  Taste of dry, citrus hops, earth, and an alcoholic twang.  A very nice biere de garde.

Clean golden beer. Nose starts out with wet dog, going into more pleasant fruity aroma with a tweek of tartness. Candy sugar with some nice hops to combine, and a nice citrusaftertaste which made the mouth happy. Good stuff.

Medium amber color with a nice head and lacing. Lightly hoppy and slightly fruity aroma, boring. Flavor is light. Slightly hoppy, light malt tones and hints of citrus fruit. Finish is stringent and unpleasing.

Bottle.  Amber color with a bit of orange.  Nice big fluffy white head.  Aroma has hints of wheaty malt and fruit.  It is nicely hopped and yeasty, but there's something I don't like about the hop in the finish that keeps it from being a really good beer.

Light bright copper color, light white head.  The nose is sweet and organic, tart and fruity.  Sweet straightforward malt body with a lot of alcohol present.  Strong yeast and a moderately long finish.  This beer didn't grab me like it did others.  Okay, I just wasn't a big fan.
Tea-amber look , with thick crown . Earthy , woody , slight roast feel . Short malty notes , nice yet simple feel .  Softer finish .

orangey brown, off white head.  malty whole whea bread and cereal and grainy aroma with a bit of caramel and a hint of peach.  flavour follows with big malty sweetness rounding out with some tart appley notes and a bit of spice in the finish.  very nice.  thanks doug!

Rich malty aroma.Medium brown amber appearance.Slightly thick mouthfeel.Interesting combination of sweet caramel,biscuits and chocolate milk flavors,fruity apricots and apples and spicy peppery hops at the finish.Thanks to Captain Cougar.
(750ml bottle) Thin, white, quick dissipating head and copper body. Nose of cereal, malt and milky rubbing alcohol. Brown sugar and hoppy smooth taste. Finishes too soon. Very good! Thanks Doug.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 Glamorous yet mellow caramel covered by an amorous flowery countryside...Milk and cereal omnipotence delivers dried apricots...Cheese perfumes from the neighbours barn...Morning rises in Northern France with a touch of alcohol still in the back of the tongue, but plenty of merriment was had, thats for sure...A spoonful of dusty and dry attic longevity meets the wealth of a thoughtul silence...
Slight hazy amber. Big, spicy head. Rich, malty mal aroma. Smooth, medium body. Warm, spicy, malty flavour.

Copper color, cream head. Earthy aroma with some spice, grass and some lighter fruits. Flavor was sweet and caramely with some funky farmhouse yeast and pear. Medium body, quite nice. Thanks DougShoemaker.

Orange tinted golden coloured body with a white head. Aroma of spices, pepper, skunk, grass and must. Medium-bodied; Nice complex taste-odd tastes like a saison. 'Farmhouse' pretty much defines it all for me. Aftertaste fairly clean compared to the aroma! I had this bottle at the Winter Party at Oakes' place in Toronto, Canada on 05-December-2003. A large amount of thanks go out to DougShoemaker for supplying this #1 ranked beer for the style to the party!

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 Copper hue with a good frothy off-white head and good lace. The aroma hinted of sweaty yeast, grain, floral and grassy hops, apple, pear, white wine, allspice, and dust. The taste started out sweet, earthy, and dusty. The finish explored a fruity, mildly tart, spicy side with a hint of bitterness. This medium to full-bodied brew had a smooth and creamy mouthfeel with a very light touch of alcohol.Wonderfully complex, sublime tones. Highly recommended for its among the best of the genre.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2003 750ml bottle

Clear, effervescent reddish-amber with a creamy tan head that starts rich and full, then shrinks to a solid cap with scattered lacing. Intoxicating malty aroma with a good dose of caramel, nuts, flowery hop, spicy and earthy yeast, and some faint fruity esters. The flavor is incredibly rich and well integrated, exploding with a blast of malt complexity. Theres some flowery hops, but theyre there mostly in a supporting role. Lots of smooth caramel and nuts, along with a fair amount of funky farmhouse yeast, adding a slightly spicy edge. Lengthy finish with some bread and hop flavor. The last half of the bottle adds a slight metallic note. Mouthfeel is perfect. Round, full, and creamy, without being anywhere near cloying. Carbonation keeps it lively, but doesnt intrude. Justperfect. This must be the most amazing bière de garde in existence...the standard to which I hold all others. DamnI could drink an ocean of this stuff!
Good Biere de Garde. Lots of flavor  malty, yeasty, and spicey.  Finishes clean, creamy, and smooth.
Malt, fruit and bread aromas. Copper, small custard head. Quite a bitter start, very malty. Medium bodied, good mouthfeel. Really fine!
Dark honey colored, pours with a frothy head.  Yeasty, spicy aroma, maybe of nutmeg and (slight) clove.  More sweet than I was expecting.  Enjoyable brew.

Pours with an amber body with orange accents topped by a medium thick off white fizzy lasting head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is sweet and decadent with notes of malt, orange peel, flowers and alcohol. Sweet malty flavor with a good bitter balance and notes of orange, licorice, alcohol and hops.  The finish is slightly bitter.  Medium to full bodied with plenty of tingling from the carbonation and a slight warming sensation.

Lots of nice scum all over the bottle cap. No cork. This looks almost scary -- lots of rust and gunk all over it. I'm decanting so as not to stir up much yeast and it pours a clean, clear browning copper. Not much yeast in the nose on the first glass -- mostly carmels. Subsequent glasses add more yeast, and I get hints of pear, lemon, creamyness, waxy crayon, pepper, dust. The more yeast the better. Love the spritzy but creamy feel -- much like a good DuPont but more brutal. Not nearly as refined as other BdGs but exciting and curious for it. I love the biere de garde style. Thanks a bunch and big congrats to Hey_Kevin -- I'm having this to salute his new baby. CHEERS!
pours a deep golden/orangeish color with a huge frothy head. very lively carbonation. aroma and flavor reminds me of grape with woody and metallic notes. also detected a hint of brown sugar.
Dark amber with a medium-tan head.  Big bubbles.  Sweet malty caramel flavors.  A grassy, bitter, dry hoppiness to the finish.  Excellent.
Very nice Orange colour, beautiful head, vanishing in about 5 minutes. I didnt really like that beer, it is very hoppy and reminded me of tuppers hop pocket ale.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2003 looked real good when poured into the glass, a weak aroma to begin with but half in the glass it smells really nice. VERY hoppy beer, nice fruity taste, a bit sour, cant wait to try some other beers in this style... I´ll buy this again, that´s for sure

This pours a slightly hazy pale amber color with a long lasting frothy head. It has lots of carbonation, but uncharacteristically, add to the drinking experience, rather than distracting from it. It has a slightly thick feel on the tongue with a subtle sweetness. The aroma has a touch of apple in it. In my opinion, this beer has a lot of small & subtle tastes & smells that add up to a very nice beer.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2003 Aroma bears a vague, sweet fruity character with perhaps some pear and caramel, slight vanilla, yeast, a very green aspect - almost like hay, a light but definite spiciness and very faint wafts of alcohol.  Medium, deep copper color, with a lasting, fine head and very delicate lacing.  Nicely balanced flavor profile, with some muscat grape notes, a very faintly toffeeish sweetness, some slight melon and nut, along with leafy, green, fresh, spicy European hops.  Medium bodied and with a silky smooth palate.  Understated and intriguing.    Surprisingly and pleasantly intoxicating as well!  An exercise in subtlety.
Sour apples, cider, floral aroma. Flavor is cidery, floral, and has a touch of sourness. Very well balanced. Very malty for a biere de garde. Very drinkable.

OK, I typed up this nice review as I sat here drinking this beer 2 days ago. When I sent it, the site went down - and I didn't take notes...I know this much: this is the best Biere de Garde I've had to date. Very aromatic, peppery, fruity. Nice mouthfeel, fairly significant carbonation, but small bead. Great well-balanced beer, with nice earthy farmhouse character. Sorry...can't remember anything else.

Greaty yeasty nose with an alcohol punch - maybe some apples there too. Lovely sparkling amber color and huge tall spongy head. Overall delicate, but very flavorful. Destinct spiciness (cinnamon, pepper) towards the end. Toffee steps forward about mid glass. Very fizzy initially - I found this better as time passed and it became less carbonated. Superb blend of malt, alcohol, and spicy hops.

Great one, has to warm up a little bit, so that all the flavors come through. Nice apple aroma. Amber with a big frothy - long staying head. Fizzy carbonation - which indeed is, as ChimayBabe said, loveley unlike at most of the beers. Fruity apple taste, light bitter note at the end, also malty. Slightly refreshing.
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2004 Caramel-orange aroma. Slight butterscotch flavor. Malty clover and some minerals. Leafy/buttery aroma. Loved the carbonation. Beautiful foamy head.

Slightly sour, citrusy aroma. Very malty body, slightest touch of sourness and some nice light fruit notes. Perfect balance. Toffee malt flavor seems to dominate and is pleasant, although detracts somewhat from the brew's complexity. Perfect balance.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2003 This one is, quite simply, exceptional.  The aroma is a very nice start, and the look of the beer is nice as well.  Flavor is very soft and deep...quite delicious really!  Great!

viva la France!  I love this beer mostly because it's from France, such a rare and beautiful find, great French beer...the fine amber body hit my palate like a warm cheese, so smooth and filling...plus, the nutmeg really rubs me the right way, I just love nutmeg

Reddish brown body, moderately carbonated, lightly bottle conditioned.  Amber malt aromas, rye, nutmeg, faint alcoholic heat, floral hops, and that certain farmhouse je ne sais quoi that I can't quite accurately describe, but I love it.  Soft, velvety mouthfeel.  Outstanding balance of rounded malt and spicy hops.  Presents a lovely lingering finish of bitterness mixed with the farmhouse character, which 30 minutes after finishing prompted me to boost my rating a bit.  Although I've only had this and Sans Culottes at this point, this style is quickly becoming one of my favorites.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2004 Rerate 9/29/04: Pours a rich copper amber with a thick, frothy, and well-lacing off-white head.  Aroma is malty and rich with a touch of butterscotchy oxidation.  Body shows some signs of age, even though I recently purchased this from a store that just got it in.  Still, it has aged fairly well on its strong malt backbone.

1/20/03: Light, clear copper colored with a thin layer of off-white head.  Has a subtle sweet malty aroma that leads into a mellow grainy flavor with a light, well balanced bitterness.  The palate is thin, but has a silky caramel feel to it and a sweet candy-like finish.  This has many of the characteristics of a good doppelbock.  I was quite impressed.

Slightly hazy copper color with a creamy head that clings to the glass even as it dissipates.  (I have notice the haze was only a chill haze, and now that the beverage has warmed it is quite a stunning dark topaz gem) Not to offend the French, but this has a real english malt nose, with a mild hopsack and farm yeast aroma.  Caramel malts and more malts in the flavors.  A bit sweet in the start but the spicy hops and alcohol take back the palate and make this a very warming ale.  Malt lingers in the finish.  Quite effervesent, but not the overflowing, big bubbly type.  Very small bubbles that tickle the roof of the mouth and tongue.  Quite smooth almost to a point of feeling thin, but thats really not the case.  This one is a great example of a balanced malty beer.  Hops do not have to rule!

Bright reddish/copper hue, big foamy head with moderately fast dissipation and good lacing.  Nose malty, caramelly, some cherry notes (flander red ale reminder), maybe just a hint of alcohol and ammonia.  Very strong and distinctive.  Flavor is wonderful, with vanilla cream at the very beginning, farmy lambic-type hints creeping in, huge malt, and an extraordinary smoothness just barely pierced by hints of alcohol and spices like cloves and coriander.  Buttery finish.  Absolutely wonderful, with one of the creamiest most quaffable textures Ive ever experienced.  Wish I had more than the one bottle.

Beautiful color of like amber honey.  The head is full and fluffy upon pouring, but reduces slightly when sitting.  The aroma is very pleasing, but not easy for me to describe.  Sweet malts, a touch of citrus, some spiciness and even of the farm.  Its still a subpar description, but the best I can do.  The beer is light and clean in the mouth.  Again, it is a pleasantly sweet with a touch of spice.  The finish is mild and refreshing.  My first of the style and certainly not to be the last.

Biere de Garde is one of my favorite styles, and this is about the best one that I have ever had.  If it was only SLIGHTLY less sweet, this would be in my top ten.  Excellent balance of hops and malt. Very well done, if you can find it, buy it!

Unfortunate green bottling may be responsible for the distinctly skunky aroma I got off this. However, the beer otherwise seemed untouched by this frequently fatal flaw. Light, sweet toffeeish malt flavor with a nice peppery spiciness. Has a good bitter snap to it as well. Eminently quaffable.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2004 Far richer malt, more apparent yeast, and softer hops in the aroma in this compared to 3 Monts, IMO. Fabulous nose. Presentation is quite dark. Lasting head as a rim around the glass. Nice soft round palate. Warms up a bit less white-winey than 3 Monts, more rounded and full. I am not a fan of Biere de Gardes, but oh my goodness this is the one to have.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 22, 2005 Beautiful!Thick glowing amber liquid with off white lasting head.It clings to the glass in a ring all the way to the end.Aroma was extremely chewy caramel,earthy,hearty and short lived spicy/sour hop aromas. Huge clean malt flavors are the showcase here.The hops are barely noticable in finish and eventually just faded away.Replaced with a sweet,winey,alcohol finish.First of its kind for me.Excellent!!Thanks for sharing,Kev!

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2009 Bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, off-white to light brown, mostly lasting. Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, toasted bread), lightly hoppy (flowers, apricot), lightly yeasty (cobwebs, basement), with notes of peach, orange peel, autumn leaves, sweet pastries. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Clean and solid.  Drier and more quaffable than I remember from many years ago, but still delightful.

Deep burnished rust in color; Head was dense, soapy and only slightly darker then eggshell; Nose was musky, hay- tiny hit of hop. Much maltier then usual. Round. Very little of the spice that I am used to in the style. Sweetness emerges at the 1/2 mark.
Decent, better than 3 Monts, I think.  Malty, medium copper color.  Tastes like a Belgian Ale, not light like a farmhouse ale.  Worth a try.  From the oldest brewery in France.

Huge head that sticks and stays until the last swallow.  Aroma hints at toasted malt, caramel, honey, peanuts, fruit, and a very subtle hint of hops.  Flavors remind me grape jam, chewy malts (like a quality Scottish ale), which showcase their complexities as well as any beer I have tried, bread, and English hops.  The mouthfeel is what will separate this from anything that dares to compete; which is creamy, very chewy, and round.  Tries to finish dry; so balanced, as hops and malt try like heck to outshine one another.  I could go through a case of this in a week.  It would pair mighty fine with many foods as well.  Scored this in Chicago and only bought one.  I highly recommend going to all the trouble it may take to find this delectable treat.  Its gotta be the best Biere de Garde on Earth.    Tantalizing!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
Saved this for a month just so it could be my 200th rating and I was not disappointed!  Initial aromas of nuts and roasted malts before settling into a smooth, deep, doughy malt nose.  This is just jam packed with malt - toffee, bready, and doughy flavors abound before moving into a balanced finish with plenty of spiciness and bitterness offset perfectly by creaminess.
Beautiful deep bronze color with a diminutive head.  A great brew.

Wow thanks to Oakes for the profile of this one which prompted me to not continue passing the biere de gardes up in favor of the lesser belgians.  Wonderful maltiness just improves as the beer warms.  Slight initial metallicness, but that faded quite quickly, leaving back an extremely tasty treat.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2004 Amber, nice full head and lace. Nose is loaded with sweet malt, hint of honey and light caramel. First thing i noticed was the softness and creaminess of the body. The palate is pure, smooth malt with notes of breadiness. Some hop spicyness with a smidge of alcohol.
Amber ale. Nice hop aroma. Good malt body, with long and aromatic final, in which sweetness and hop alternate, like waves. Great.
Hoppy, malts, bit sweet.

Fiery amber colour with an even, creamy head; smooth malt aroma and palate. This, ladies and gentlemen, is a clinic on malt extraction.  My god these flavours are sublime.  Smooth, slightly spicy, creamy, malt palate. There are very few brewers who are operating at this level.  Armand Theillier, make me some more beers.  Please.
